yoruba: Ó dá mi lójú pé "Ìyá àgbà" yìí yóò ṣòro tí ó wúni lórí ju Ilham Aliyev lọ.

english: Muntazir's reference to “Grandma Saray” addresses Aliyev's visit to the Shamakhi region of Azerbaijan, where an earthquake destroyed several homes earlier this month, including one belonging to a 92-year-old woman called Saray.
yoruba: Ìfakùn ọ̀rọ̀ “Ìyá àgbà Saray” tí Muntazir mẹ́nubà dá lórí àbẹ̀wò ìbánidárọ tí Aliyev bá lọ sí Agbègbè Shamakhi tí Azerbaijan, níbi tí ìporùrù ayé tí bá ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ilé ìgbé jẹ́ ní ìbẹ̀rẹ̀ oṣù yìí, tí ọ̀kan nínú rẹ̀ jẹ́ ti obìrin ọlọ́mọdún 92 tí orúkọ rẹ ń jẹ́ Saray.

english: State propaganda had seized on Aliyev's meeting with Saray, who has since been celebrated as a model citizen for her stoicism and faith in the future of the Azerbaijani state after the quake.
yoruba: Ajábọ̀ iṣẹ́ ìjọba ti fúnpá lórí ìpàdé tí Aliyev ní pẹ̀lú Saray, ẹni tí ó ti gba oríyìn gẹ́gẹ́ bí àwòkọ́ṣe rere fún ìfaradà àti ìgbàgbọ́ tí ó ní sí ọjọ́ iwájú orílẹ̀-èdè Azerbaijan lẹ́yìn-in ìṣẹ́lẹ̀ náà.

english: Ilham Aliyev meets with Grandma Saray. Photo from qafkaz.info.
yoruba: Ilham Aliyev pàdé Ìyá àgbà Saray. Àwòrán láti qafkaz.info.

english: As can be seen from an abridged translation of the REAL TV interview, Aliyev went overboard in his praise for the elderly citizen, name-checking her seven times in quick succession:
yoruba: Bí a ṣe lè ri lára ìtú ìmọ̀ ìfọ̀rọ̀wọ́rọ̀ agbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ REAL TV l'órèfé, Aliyev sọ àsọdùn ọ̀rọ̀ nínú ìgbóríyìn fún arúgbó ọ̀hún, bí ò tí ṣe perí rẹ ní sísẹ̀ntẹ̀lé:

english: Such grandmothers and mothers, like Grandma Saray, have been preserving our national and spiritual values ​​for centuries.
yoruba: Irú ìyá àgbà àti àwọn ìyá, gẹ́gẹ́ bíi Ìyá àgbà Saray ti ń ṣakitiyan ìpamọ́ àwọn ìṣe orílẹ̀ wa àti ẹ̀mí-àìrí fún àìní ye ọgọ́rùn-ún ọdún.

english: Every Azerbaijani woman wants to be akin to grandmothers Saray.
yoruba: Gbogbo obìnrin Azerbaijan ni ó fẹ́ fi ìwà jọ ìyá àgbà Saray.

english: Look, a 92-year-old woman whose house is destroyed, how much optimism in this woman!
yoruba: Wò ó, obìrin ọmọ ọdún 92 èyí tí ilé rẹ̀ ti di ìlẹ̀ẹ́lẹ̀, ìrètí gidi wo ló tún wà fún un mọ́!

english: Grandma Saray is confident that the state will be with her.
yoruba: Ìyá àgbà Saray ní ìfọkàntẹ̀ pé ìjọba yóò dúró tì òun.

english: Honestly, during a trip to Shamakhi, I did not know that I would meet Grandma Saray.
yoruba: Kámáparọ́, nínú ìrìnàjò kékeré lọ sí Shamakhi, n kò rò ó tì tẹ́lẹ̀ pé n ó ṣe àlábàpáàdé Ìyá àgbà Saray.

english: I examined the houses affected by the earthquake, familiarized myself with the situation there.
yoruba: Mo yẹ àwọn ilé tí ìporùrù ilẹ̀ ọ̀hún bà wò fínnífínní, mo sì rí àrító ohun tí ó ṣẹlẹ̀ níbẹ̀.

english: When I saw Grandma Saray, I was once again convinced of how great the people of Azerbaijan were.
yoruba: Gẹ́gẹ́ tí mo rí Ìyá àgbà Saray, àrídájú mi lórí bí àwọn ọmọ Azerbaijan ṣe ṣ'èèyàn sí l'ékún sí i.

english: We can be proud of our people.
yoruba: Àwọn ọmọ ilẹ̀ wa á máa mú ìwúrí báni.

english: She was in a difficult situation; her house was destroyed.
yoruba: Ó wà nínú ìṣòro; ilée rẹ̀ ti wó.

english: She probably did not even know that someone would come to her aid.
yoruba: Ó jọ pé kò mọ̀ pé ẹnìkan yóò wá ṣe ìrànwọ́ fún òun.

english: She did not know whether her house would be repaired or a new house would be built.
yoruba: Kò mọ̀ bóyá ilé òun yóò dí àtúnkọ́ tàbí wọn yóò dà á wó pátápátá kọ́ òmíràn.

english: Grandmothers like Saray are the embodiment of the unbending spirit of the Azerbaijani people.
yoruba: Àwọn ìyá àgbà bíi Saray ní ẹ̀mí ìforítì òun ìlọra tí ó mú àwọn ọmọ Orílẹ̀ Azerbaijan yàtọ̀.

english: Another independent journalist, Sevinc Osmangizi, staged a call in canvassing reactions to the interview on YouTube immediately after the interview was broadcast.
yoruba: Oníròyìn aládàádúró mìíràn, Sevinc Osmangizi, fi ṣe àgbékalẹ̀ ìpè kan ní oríi YouTube tí ó ń pè fún ìda-ọ̀rọ̀-wo lórí ìfọ̀rọ̀wáni-lẹ́nuwo ọ̀hún lẹ́yìn tí Ìgbóhùnsáfẹ́fẹ́ parí.

english: Viewers mostly registered their disappointment and called for change.
yoruba: Àwọn tí wọ́n wò ó sọ àwọn nǹkan tí kò tẹ́ wọn lọ́run, wón sì tún pè fún àyípadà.

english: One said:
yoruba: Ọ̀kan ní:

english: I could not watch the interview any longer and I turned off the television.
yoruba: N kò le è wo ìfọ̀rọ̀wọ́rọ̀ náà ju ibi mo wò ó dé lọ, mo sì pa ẹ̀rọ amóhùn-máwòrán.

english: Because both the interviewer Mirshahin Aghayev and his questions were very fake.
yoruba: Nítorí pé, òfé lásán ni olùbéèrè Mirshahin Aghayev àti ìbéèrè rẹ̀.

english: Their promises to us is no longer matter.
yoruba: Àdéhùn wọn kò wúlò fún wa mọ́.

english: Because people are now tired of such frauds and lies.
yoruba: Èké àti irọ́ wọn ti sú àwọn èèyàn.

english: People want innovations and real reforms.
yoruba: Àwọn ará ìlú ń fẹ́ ohun tuntun àti àtúntò tòótọ́.

english: A Tibetan-Canadian student was attacked online after winning student council elections.
yoruba: Akẹ́kọ̀ọ́bìrin kan tí ó jẹ́ ọmọ Tibet-Canada rí ìkọlu lórí ayélujára lẹ́yìn tí ó já ewé olú borí nínú ìdìbò àjọ-ìgbìmọ̀ akẹ́kọ̀ọ́.

english: She thinks Beijing is to blame.
yoruba: Ó rò pé, Beijing ló yẹ á bá wí.

english: Image from Chemi Lhamo Instagram via The Stand News.
yoruba: Àwòrán wá láti ọwọ́ọ Chemi Lhamo láti ìbáwọlé The Stand News.

english: This article was originally written by Leung Hoi Ching and published in Chinese on Hong Kong based citizen media, the Stand News on February 15, 2018.
yoruba: Leung Hoi Ching ni ó kọ́kọ́ kọ ìròyìn yìí tí a sì tẹ̀jáde ní èdèe Chinese lórí ilé ìgbéròyìn jáde ará ìlú Hong Kong, The Stand News ní ọjọ́ karùn-ún-dínlógún, Oṣù Èrèlé, ọdún-un 2019.

english: The following trimmed English version is translated by Zhao Yunlin.
yoruba: Zhao Yunlin ni ó tú ìmọ̀ọ rẹ̀ sí èdèe Gẹ̀ẹ́sì.

english: On February 9, students at the University of Toronto's Scarborough Campus elected Chemi Lhamo, a 22-year-old student of Tibetan origin, as their student council president.
yoruba: Ní ọjọ́ kẹsàn-án Oṣù Èrélé, àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ti Ifáfitì Toronto, ọgbà Scarborough dìbò yan ọmọ ọdún méjìlél'ógún kan tí ìlú abínibíi rẹ̀ jẹ́ Tibet, gẹ́gẹ́ bí ààrẹ ìgbìmọ̀ àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́.

english: Just days after the election results were announced, thousands of mainland Chinese overseas students signed an online petition of protest, accusing Lhamo of having close associations with pro-Tibet independence organizations.
yoruba: Lẹ́yìn ọjọ́ mélòó kan tí a kéde èsì ìdìbò ọ̀hún, ogunlọ́gọ̀ àwọn ọmọ China tí wọ́n ń kẹ́kọ̀ọ́ l'ókè òkun fi òǹtẹ̀ lu àpilẹ̀kọ ìfi-èhónú kan ní orí ẹ̀rọ-ayélujára, tí wọ́n sì ń t'ọ́ka àbùkù sí Lhamo pé ó ń l'ẹ̀díàpòpọ̀ pẹ̀lú àwọn àjọ tó ń jà fún òmìnira Tibet.

english: They demanded the school disqualify her from the elected position.
yoruba: Wọn rọ àwọn aláṣẹ ilé-ìwé ọ̀hún láti yọ ọ́ kúrò l'órí òye náà.

english: Demeaning comments from overseas mainland Chinese students
yoruba: Kòbákùngbé ìfèsì ọ̀rọ̀ láti ẹnu àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ tí ó ń gbé ní òkè òkun gbùngbùn òkè-odò China.

english: Lhamo’s personal social account was flooded with demeaning comments and veiled threats of violence from overseas students who appeared to be from mainland China.
yoruba: Ìṣàmúlò ẹ̀rọ-alátagbàa ti Lhamo kún fún àwọn kòbákùngbé ìjábọ̀-ọ̀rọ̀ àti èyí tí ó ń pè fún ìwàa jàgídíjàgan, èyí tí kò ṣẹ̀yìn àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ òkè-òkun tí ó ń gbé gbùngbùn China.

english: As her story began to make headlines in international media outlets, students from Hong Kong and Taiwan fired back in defense Lhamo's defense.
yoruba: Bí àwọn ilé ìgbéròyìn sáfẹ́fẹ́ àgbàńlá-ayé gbogbo ṣe tán ìròyìn-in rẹ̀ ká, àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ tí ó wà láti Hong Kong àti Taiwan gbìnnàyá láti gbéjàa Lhamo.

english: In a phone interview with Stand News, Chemi Lhamo said she believed that the incident was mobilized by organizations associated with Chinese government, an accusation that Chinese officials have denied.
yoruba: Nínú ìfọ̀rọ̀wáni-lẹ́nuwo orí ẹ̀rọ ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ pẹ̀lú Stand News, Chemi Lhamo sọ pé òun nígbàgbọ́ pé ohun tí ó ṣẹlẹ̀ kò sẹ́yìn àwọn àjọ tí wọ́n ń bá Ìjọba China ṣe, ẹ̀sùn èyí tí àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ àgbà àjọ ọba China ti sẹ́ lé lórí.

english: Before this election, I had already been elected as vice-president of the student council for eight whole months and nothing ever happened.
yoruba: Kí a tó dìbò yìí, a ti yàn mí gẹ́gẹ́ bí igbá-kejì ààrẹ ìgbìmọ̀ akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ fún oṣù mẹ́jọ gbáko, kò sì sí ohun kan tí ó ṣẹlẹ̀.

english: However, after all these sudden events, you cannot help but think that there is an organization manipulating these events behind the scenes.
yoruba: Ní ìdakèjì, lẹ́yìn gbogbo ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ẹ pàjáwìrì wọ̀nyìí, kò sí àní-àní pé àjọ kan ń gbìyànjú láti tìka bọ ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ wọ̀nwọ̀nyí ní bírípó.

english: It’s really funny how I’ve been serving as a vice-president for so long, how I’ve organized many events and never held back from expressing my ideals, but nobody has ever asked me about my political opinions.
yoruba: Ó pani lẹ́rìn-ín pé láti ìgbà yìí wá tí mo ti ń ṣiṣẹ́ gẹ́gẹ́ bí igbá-kejì ààrẹ, bí mo ti ṣe ń ṣe ètò oríṣiríṣi tí n ò sì yé fi àwọn àṣàyàn ìhùwàsí mi l'éde, ṣùgbọ́n kò sí ẹni tí ó ti wádìí nípa àwọn ọ̀nà òṣèlú tí mo yàn ní ààyò.

english: She also said that her fellow students from mainland China began to behave strangely.
yoruba: Ó tẹ̀ síwájú sí i pé ìwà àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ akẹgbẹ́ òun láti gbùngbùn China tí ń yí padà.

english: One of Lhamo’s classmates from mainland China spontaneously asked her, via mobile message, to draft a statement regarding Tibetan independence.
yoruba: Ọ̀kàn nínú àwọn akẹgbẹ́ẹ rẹ̀ tí ó wá láti gbùngbùn China fi ìwàǹwara pè é níjà láti fi èrò rẹ s'óde lórí gbígba òmìnira Tibet.

english: She also received phone calls playing "red songs" (propaganda songs praising the Chinese Communist Party).
yoruba: Ó tún gba àwọn ìpè kan, èyí tí ó ń kọ "orin pupa" (orin ọ̀tẹ̀ tí ó ń yín Ẹgbẹ́ Òṣèlú Chinese Communist Party).

english: Lhamo could not understand these songs, as she does not speak Mandarin Chinese.
yoruba: Àwọn orin wọ̀nyìí kò yé Lhamo, bó ṣe jẹ́ pé kò mọ èdèe Mandarin Ilẹ̀ China sọ.

english: Alongside the joint attacks and the comments on the internet, a group of students went to the student council office to demand that the election results be reconsidered.
yoruba: Bí àkànlù àtakò àti ìjàbọ̀ ṣe ń lọ lọ́wọ́ lórí ayélujára, àpapọ̀ àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ kan tí gbógun lọ sí ọ́fíìsì ìgbìmọ̀ akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ láti lọ pè fún gbígbé èsì ìdìbò ọ̀hún yẹ̀wò.

english: The campus student council has now temporarily closed its conference room, for safety reasons.
yoruba: Ìgbìmọ̀ akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ sì ti ti ìyàrá ìpàdée wọn pa fún ìgbà díẹ̀, nítorí ọ̀rọ̀ àbò.

english: Chemi Lhamo has been a student activist for some years.
yoruba: Chemi Lhamo ti jẹ́ ajàjàǹgbara akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ fún ọdún mélòó kan.

english: She is an active member of the Tibetan community in Toronto and once joined a protest outside the university's Confucius Institute, the local branch of a global network of Chinese cultural institutions that are sponsored by the Chinese government and intended to promote China's soft power overseas.
yoruba: Ó jẹ́ ọmọ ẹgbẹ́ tó ní áápọn ní ìlú àjọgbé àwọn Tibet tí ó wà ní Toronto àti pé ó ti kópa nínú ìjàfẹ́tọ̀ọ́ kan tí ó wáyé níta Akànkọ́ Ilé Ẹ̀kọ́ Confucius tí fáfitì ọ̀hún, ẹ̀ka ìbílẹ̀ àjọ ìsọdọ̀kan àṣà Ilẹ̀ China tí ìjọba China ń ṣe agbátẹrù fún lọ́nà tí ó fi ń mú kí China lágbára sí i ní ilẹ̀ òkèèrè.

english: In recent years, she has also exchanged views with social activists from Hong Kong and Taiwan on topics related to freedom of speech, self-determination, democracy and related topics at public events.
yoruba: Ní ìgbà yìí wá, ó ti fi èrò ọkàn-an rẹ̀ hàn pẹ̀lú àwọn ajàfẹ́tọ̀ọ́ ìlú láti Hong Kong àti Taiwan lórí kókó ọ̀rọ̀ tó jẹ mọ̀, òmìnira ọ̀rọ̀ sísọ, ìdá-gbé nǹkan ṣe, ìjọba àwarawa àti àwọn kókó tó jọ mọ́ ọ ní ìpàdé ìta gbangba.

english: Lhamo has never been afraid to speak up or show her Tibetan identity – she wears a Chuba, the traditional Tibetan dress, every Wednesday.
yoruba: Lhamo ò fi ìgbà kan bẹ̀rù láti sọ èrò ọkàn-an rẹ̀ jáde rí tàbí fi ara rẹ̀ hàn gẹ́gẹ́ bí ọmọ Tibet- ó má ń wọ Chuba, aṣọ ìbílẹ̀ àwọn ọmọ Tibet, ní gbogbo ọjọ́ Ọjọ́rú.

english: Until the election, she had never perceived any animosity from her Chinese classmates.
yoruba: Títí di ìgbà ìdìbò, kò gbó-òórùn inúnibíni kán rí láti ọ̀dọ àwọn akẹgbẹ́ẹ rẹ̀ tí wọ́n jẹ́ ọmọ China.

english: This is what led her to worry that this barrage of harassment was instigated by Chinese authorities.
yoruba: Èyí ni ó mú u fura pé ìkoni síta bíi ọmọ ọjọ́ mẹ́jọ yìí kò sẹ́yìn àwọn aláṣẹ China.

english: From stateless refugee to student council president
yoruba: Láti èèyàn ogúnléndé aláìníbùgbé sí olórí ìgbìmọ̀ akẹ́kọ̀ọ́

english: Before immigrating to Canada at 11 years of age, Chemi Lhamo was a stateless refugee residing in India. Her grandparents were forced into exile along with the Dalai Lama in 1959.
yoruba: Kí ó tó rin ìrìnàjò lọ sí Canada ní ọmọ ọdún mọ́kànlá , Chemi Lhamo jẹ́ ẹni ogúnléndé tí kò rí ibùgbé kan gbé ní India.

english: Within these rigid borders, no matter where she and her family went, they were looked down upon.
yoruba: Àwọn òbíi rẹ̀ àgbà sá kúrò ní ilẹ̀ẹ wọn pẹ̀lú Dalai Lama ní ọdún-un 1959. Nínú hàhámọ́ ìnira tí wọ́n wà yìí, kò sí ibi tí òun àti mọ̀lẹ́bí rẹ̀ lọ, tí wọ́n kà wọ́n kún.

english: Every time someone asks me: "Where are you from?"
yoruba: Nígbàkúùgbà tí wọ́n bá bí mí léèrè pé : "Ibo lo ti wá?"

english: I always end up struggling to answer – I sometimes say that I’m from India, but I was denied citizenship status there; sometimes I say that I’m from Tibet, but when they ask me how Tibet is like, I really don’t know how to answer, because the Chinese embassy won’t even issue me a visa to go to Tibet.
yoruba: Ara mi máa ń kótì láti dáhùn – Ìgbà mìíràn mà á pé India ni mo ti wá, ṣùgbọ́n wọn kò fún mi ní ìwé ìgbèlùú; nígbà mìíràn ẹ̀wẹ̀ mà á dáhùn pé Tibet ni mo ti wá, ṣùgbọ́n tí wọ́n bá béèrè pé báwo ni Tibet ṣe rí, n ò mọ bí n ó ṣe dáhùn-un rẹ̀, ìdí ni pé China ò fún mi ní ìwé ìgbèlùú lọ sí Tibet.

english: But it’s this experience of being viewed as an outsider that has made me understand my people’s culture better: the Tibetan culture.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ìrírí mi bí wọ́n ṣe ń rí mi bíi atọ̀húnrìnwá ti jẹ́ kí n ní ìmọ̀ nípa àṣà àwọn èèyàn mi: àṣà Tibet.

english: Lhamo recounted that when she had just immigrated to Canada, a new kid from Tibet unexpectedly came to class.
yoruba: Llamo sọ̀rọ̀ nípa ìrìnàjòo rẹ̀ lọ sí Canada, ọmọ kékeré akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ tuntun kan tí ó wá láti Tibet tí ó bá wá sí ìyàrá ìkẹ́ẹ̀kọ̀ọ́.

english: She was excited and happy to have found someone from her own land to become friends with, and she knew that he could speak the Tibetan language.
yoruba: Ara rẹ̀ yá gágá, inú rẹ̀ dùn láti ṣe alábàpàdé àwọn ọ̀rẹ́ tí ó wá láti ilẹ̀ẹ rẹ̀, bẹ́ẹ̀ ló mọ̀ pé ó lé sọ èdè Tibet.

english: However, frowning at her, he told her: “How about we don’t speak Tibetan?
yoruba: Síbẹ̀síbẹ̀, nínú ìfún-ojúpọ̀, ó sọ fún un pé: “Tí a kò bá sọ èdè Tibet ńkọ́ ?

english: I can speak English.”
yoruba: Mo lè sọ Gẹ̀ẹ́sì.”

english: I don’t know if he was either ashamed or had some kind of guilt.
yoruba: N ò mọ̀ bóyá ojú ń tì í ni tàbí ẹ̀rí ọkàn ń jẹ́ ẹ.

english: I really don’t know.
yoruba: N ò mọ̀.

english: But it was then when I realized that some young Tibetans don’t want to speak their own language as if they were being pressured to speak another language.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ìgbà náà ni mo tó mọ̀ pé àwọn ọ̀dọ́ Tibet kan ò fẹ́ sọ èdè wọn bí ẹni pé wọn kàn-án nípa fún wọn láti sọ èdè elédè.

english: At the time, Lhamo was only 12 years old.
yoruba: Ní ìgbà yẹn, Lhamo jẹ́ ọmọ ọdún 12.

english: Feeling insecure about her identity, she convinced her parents to move back to a neighborhood with a Tibetan community.
yoruba: Ẹ̀míi rẹ̀ ò lé ‘lẹ̀ nípa ìdánimọ̀ọ rẹ̀, ó yìí ọkàn àwọn òbí rẹ̀ padà láti kó lọ sí àdúgbò tí àwọn ọmọ Tibet ń gbé.

english: From then on, she learned more about Tibetan language, culture and Buddhism and became an activist.
yoruba: Láti ìgbà náà wá, ó kọ́ nípa èdè, àṣà àti ìṣẹ̀ṣe Buddha ti Tibet, ó sì di àjà-fún-ẹ̀tọ́ ọmọ ènìyàn.

english: Tibetan values, such as be considerate, be respectful to the elderly, ignorance as the root for negativity and etc., has give me a lot of strength.
yoruba: Àwọn àdáyanrí ìwà Tibet bíi ìní elẹgbẹ́ ẹni lọ́kàn, ìbọ̀wọ̀ fún àgbà, àìmọ̀kan ní ìpilẹ̀ ìbàjẹ́, ti fún mi ní ìgboyà.

english: And the more I understand my culture, the more confident I feel.
yoruba: Bí ìmọ̀ mi ṣe ń lé kún sí i nínú àṣà ìbílẹ̀ẹ mi, ní ìgboyà mi ṣe ń pọ̀ sí i.

english: This strength and confidence, she says, has enabled her to speak up as an immigrant and a Tibetan:
yoruba: Agbára àti ìgboyà yìí, bí ó ṣe sọ, tí mú u láti lè sọ̀rọ̀ akin gẹ́gẹ́ bí atọ̀hùn-rìnwá àti ọmọ Tibet:

english: Being an immigrant is very difficult, but this struggle is what makes me who I am.
yoruba: Ó le láti jẹ́ atọ̀hùn-rìnwá, ṣùgbọ́n ìjàjàǹgbara yìí ní ó sọ mí di bí mo ṣe wà.

english: Today, I speak about the Tibetan people loud and clear with pride thanks to the strength that my identity as a Tibetan gives me.
yoruba: Lónìí, mò ń sọ̀rọ̀ ní ohùn ìrara nípa àwọn ará Tibet ní kíkankíkan àti ìwúrí ọlọ́pẹ́ tí ìdánimọ̀ọ mi gẹ́gẹ́ bí ọmọ Tibet fún mi.

english: During the student council election, I often emphasize the need for the marginalized to have their own representation during the student council elections.
yoruba: Nígbà tí à ń dìbò ìgbìmọ̀ akẹ́kọ̀ọ́, mo máa ń tẹnu mọ ọn pé ó yẹ kí àwọn tí wọ́n ayàsọ́tọ̀ ní aṣojú nígbà ìdìbò.

english: We need representation so that our rights be upheld.
yoruba: À ń fẹ́ aṣojú tí yóò rí i wípé à ń rí ẹtọ wa gbà lóòrèkóòrè.

english: Suffering will end
yoruba: Ìjìyà yóò wá sópin

english: For Lhamo, the ideal world is one without borders or boundaries — Tibetan independence and autonomy is not the real issue at stake.
yoruba: Fún Lhamo, ayé tí ó pé pérépéré ni èyí tí kò sí ìdálọ́wọ́kọ́ tàbí ìyàsọ́tọ̀ — Òmìnira Tibet àti ìdádúróo rẹ̀ kọ́ ni ohun tí ó hún jẹ wá lẹ́sẹ̀.

english: My vision for Tibet is the same vision that I have for the whole world: I wish for Tibetan people to enjoy the same rights as Canadians, namely freedom to express themselves, freedom of belief, freedom to avoid political oppression.
yoruba: Ìmísí ọjọ́ ọ̀la mi sí Tibet kan náà ni mo ní sì gbogbo àgbá-ńlá-ayé: Mo fẹ́ jẹ́ kí ẹ̀tọ́ tí àwọn ará Tibet ń jẹ gbádùn máà yàtọ̀ sí ti àwọn Canada, àwọn ni òmìnira láti lè sọ èrò ọkàn ẹni, òmìnira láti ní ìgbàgbọ́, òmìnira láti máà fi òṣèlú pá ẹniẹlẹ́ni lẹ́kún.

english: I don’t only wish for Tibetan people to enjoy these rights, I also wish that people from Hong Kong and Taiwan, Eastern Turks, the 60 million refugees around the world and for everyone to enjoy these rights.
yoruba: N ò ṣe ojúṣàájú fún àwọn ará Tibet láti ní àwọn ẹ̀tọ́ wọn yìí nìkan, ó wù mí kí àwọn tí wọ́n wá láti Hong Kong àti Taiwan, ìwọ̀-oòrùn Turkey, àwọn ẹgbẹẹgbẹ̀rún lọ́nà ẹgbẹ̀rún ní ìlọ́po méjì 60 ẹni ogúnléndé tí ó wà ní kárí ayé àti fún gbogbo àwọn ènìyàn láti jàǹfààní ẹ̀tọ̀ wọ̀nyí.

english: Many people in Hong Kong believe that China has become more authoritarian in recent years, adopting a more heavy-handed policy towards political dissidents and ethnic minorities.
yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀ àwọn èèyàn láti Hong Kong ní ìgbàgbọ́ pé China tí ń lo agbára tìkúùkú, wọ́n sì ń lo ètò ìlú láti ṣẹ́ àwọn ọ̀tá àti àwọn ẹ̀yà tí kò pọ̀ lẹ́yìn.

english: Even in Hong Kong, the space for freedom of speech and association has diminished.
yoruba: Kódà ni Hong Kong, àyè láti sọ ọ̀rọ̀ ẹnu ẹni jáde àti láti bá èèyàn ṣe pọ̀ ti jákulẹ̀.

english: Chemi Lhamo is familiar with the political challenges faced in Hong Kong after the 2014 Umbrella movement but she shared her optimism with Hong Kong people and urged them not to give up:
yoruba: Àwọn ìpèníjà òṣèlú tí ó ń kojú wọn ní Hong Kong lẹ́yìn Àkójọpọ̀ Ẹgbẹ́ Alábùradà; 2014 Umbrella Movement kò ṣe àjòjì sí Chemi Lhamo, ṣùgbọ́n ó bá àwọn ará Hong Kong kẹ́dùn, ó pẹ̀tù sí wọn lọ́kàn pé kò kí wọ́n máà ṣe juwọ́ sílẹ̀:

english: I learned a concept from the Tibetan culture known as impermanence: everything has an end and I believe that all suffering will also end…I hope that one day I’ll be able to go to Tibet wearing my Chuba.
yoruba: Mo kọ́ ẹ̀kọ́ kan nínú àṣà àwọn Tibet nípa àìwàfúnìgbàpípẹ́: gbogbo nǹkan ni òpin yóò dé bá. Mo ní ìgbàgbọ́ pé ìjìyà gbogbo ń bọ̀ wá dópin…Mo ní ìrètí pé ọjọ́ kan ń bọ̀ tí mo máa wọ aṣọ Chuba mi lọ sí Tibet.

english: A steep price hike for passport applications pushed Angolans to protest
yoruba: Àfilé iye owó fún gbígba ìwé ẹ̀rí ọmọ-ìlú-fún-ìrìnnà mú àwọn ọmọ Angola fi ẹ̀hónú hàn

english: At a protest in Luanda, the sign says "30.500 Kwanzas is a lot".
yoruba: Ní ibi ìfẹ̀hónúhàn ní Luanda, àmì náà sọ pé "30.500 Kwanzas kì í ṣe kékeré".

english: Photo by Fernando Gomes, used with permission.
yoruba: Àwòrán láti ọwọ́ọ Fernando Gomes, a gba àṣẹ láti lò ó.

english: Angolans are enraged about the government's new passport fee of 30,500 kwanzas (around 97 US dollars), introduced on 21 January.
yoruba: Inú ń bí àwọn ọmọ orílẹ̀-èdè Angola látàrí iye owó ìwé ẹ̀rí ọmọ-ìlú-fún-ìrìnnà tuntun 30,500 kwanzas (ó tó 97 owó dollar) tí ìjọba ṣẹ̀ṣẹ̀ polongo ní ọjọ́ 21 oṣù Ṣẹẹrẹ.

english: Previously, the fee costed 2500 kwanzas (8 US dollars).
yoruba: 2500 kwanzas (owó dollar orílẹ̀-èdè US mẹ́jọ) ni ó jẹ́ tẹ́lẹ̀tẹ́lẹ̀.

english: In addition, the government has put in place a new price scale for all types of travel.
yoruba: Ní àfikún, ìjọba ti pín iye owó irúfẹ́ ìrìnàjò tí ó wà sí ọ̀tọ̀ọ̀tọ̀, ó tò ó ní ẹsẹẹsẹ.

english: It states that authorities will charge 45,250 kwanzas for a staying visa; 21,350 for a tourist visa; 36,500 for tourist visas given at the border; 38,125 for extensions of working visas; 15,250 for medical visas; and 30,500 for a permanent residency card.
yoruba: Lábẹ́ ìlànà tuntun yìí ni ìjọba yóò ti máa gba 45,250 kwanzas fún ìwé ìwọ̀lú ìdúró-sí-ìlú; 21,350 fún ìwé ìwọ̀lú ìrìnàjò-afẹ́; 36,500 fún ìwé ìwọ̀lú àgbàníbodè; 38,125 fún ìsúnsíwájú ìwé ìwọ̀lú iṣẹ́; 15,250 fún ìwé ìwọ̀lú ọ̀rọ̀ ìlera ara; àti 30,500 fún ìwé pélébé ìgbélùú.

english: Valdemar José, spokesperson for the Interior Ministry, told Angola Press that the price rise for ordinary passports was justified by the higher cost of producing the document:
yoruba: Agbẹnusọ fún Ẹ̀ka Ìjọba tí ó ń ṣe àbójútó ètò ìforúkọsílẹ̀, Valdemar José, sọ fún àwọn akọ̀ròyìn ìbílẹ̀ Angola pé ìdíyelé fún ìwé ìrìnnà ìwọ̀lú lásán-làsàn lọ sí òkè nítorí owó gegere ni ó ń jẹ láti ṣe ìwé náà:

english: Translation Original Quote
yoruba: Ìtúmọ̀ Ìtúnwí-ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́rọ̀ gan-an

english: The government adjusted the real value of the passport and stopped subsidising it, giving, for example, priority to issues of water, light and products of primary necessity.
yoruba: Ìjọba rí i wípé ó tó àsìkò láti sún owó ìwé ẹ̀rí ọmọ-ìlú-fún-ìrìnnà, ó sì ti yọ ọwọ́ọ Kílàńkóo rẹ̀ kúrò nínú kíkó owó lé e lórí, kí ó ba lè ṣe, fún àpẹẹrẹ, pèsè omi, ináa mànàmáná àti àwọn ohun amáyérọrùn mìíràn.

english: The materials for producing passports have a higher cost, because of the security features in the documents, which until now the state subsidised.
yoruba: Ohun èlò fún ìwé ẹ̀rí ọmọ-ìlú-fún-ìrìnnà máa ń gbọ́n owó mì, nítorí iṣẹ́ ìdáàbòbò oríi rẹ̀, tí àjọ ọba ń kówó lé lórí tẹ́lẹ̀ kí ó tó di ìgbà yìí.

english: This is reminiscent of what Mozambicans experienced in late 2018, when the government also decided to increase the fees for legal documents, as well as for driving licenses, by 500 per cent.
yoruba: Èyí jẹ́ ìrántí ohun tí ojú àwọn ọmọ Mozambique rí ní ìparí ọdún-un 2018, nígbàtí ìjọba pinnu láti fi owó kún ìwé àṣẹ gbogbo, bẹ́ẹ̀ náà ni ó bá ìwé àṣẹ ọkọ̀ wíwà, tí ìdíyelée rẹ̀ fi ìdá 500 gbéwó lórí.

english: The price hike has sparked controversy.
yoruba: Àfilé iye owó náà ti dá awuyewuye sílẹ̀.

english: A protest by around 100 youths took place on 4 February, and was promoted by a group of citizens who saw the government’s measure as a clear attempt to restrict people’s right to travel.
yoruba: Ìfẹ̀hónúhàn ọ̀dọ̀ tí ó tó bíi 100 wáyé ní ọjọ́ kẹ́rin oṣù Èrèlé, pẹ̀lú àtìlẹ́yìn ẹgbẹ́ àwọn ọmọ ìlú kan tí ó rí ìgbésẹ̀ ìjọba gẹ́gẹ́ bí ọ̀nà láti gbẹ́sẹ̀ lé ẹ̀tọ́ àwọn ènìyàn fún ìrìnàjò ṣíṣe.

english: The protest
yoruba: Ìfẹ̀hónúhàn náà

english: Protest in Luanda (4 February).
yoruba: Ìfẹ̀hónúhàn ní Luanda (ọjọ́ kẹrin oṣù Èrèlé).

english: Photo by Simão Rossi, used with permission.
yoruba: Àwòrán láti ọwọ́ọ Simão Rossi, a lò ó pẹ̀lú àṣẹ.

english: On 4 February, Global Voices spoke with Fernando Gomes, an Angolan activist and one of the promoters of the protest, to learn more of the details around the event.
yoruba: Ní ọjọ́ kẹrin oṣù Èrèlé, Global Voices bá Fernando Gomes, ajìjàǹgbara ọmọ orílẹ̀ èdè Angola tí ó jẹ́ ọ̀kan lára àwọn alátìlẹ́yìn ìfẹ̀hónúhàn náà tàkùrọ̀sọ, láti mọ ohun gbogbo tí ó rọ̀ mọ́ ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ náà.

english: He told us:
yoruba: Ó sọ fún wa:

english: Translation Original Quote
yoruba: Ìtúmọ̀ Ìtúnwí-ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́rọ̀ gan-an

english: This [was the] way found to attract the attention of João Lourenço’s government, that this is not the best time to increase the price, as citizens lose purchasing power in an exponential way.
yoruba: Èyí [ni ọ̀nà kan] fún ìpèsí àkíyèsí ìjọba João Lourenço, wípé àfilé ìdíyelé kò yẹ nírú àsìkò yìí, nítorí owó náà ti ṣe gegere ju fún àwọn ọmọ ìlú.

english: And that the much alluded to "diversification of the Angolan economy" cannot occur exclusively through raising direct taxes, given that they only hit citizens, the political class has various privileges, which are paid for by the already impoverished citizens themselves.
yoruba: Àti pé "iṣẹ́ ìdàgbàsókè ọrọ̀ Ajé orílẹ̀-èdè Angola" kò lé wáyé nípasẹ̀ àfilé owó orí, nítorí wípé àwọn ọmọ ìlú ni ó ń fi orí kó o, àwọn tí ó wà ní ipò ìjọba ní àǹfààní tí ó pọ̀ ní ìkáwọ́ọ wọn, tí ó ṣe pé àpò ará ìlú tí ó ń rùnpà ni wọ́n ti ń mú owó tí wọ́n ń ná.

english: Critics say that it is important to remember that a passport is a citizen’s identity document abroad and, as such, an inescapable necessity for a lot of citizens.
yoruba: Àwọn alátakò ti sọ pé ó ṣe pàtàkì láti rántí wípé ìwé ẹ̀rí ọmọ-ìlú-fún-ìrìnnà dúró fún ìdánimọ̀ ọmọ ìlú ní òkè òkun, torí ìdí èyí, kò ṣe é yẹ̀ sílẹ̀ fún wọn.

english: Translation Original Quote
yoruba: Ìtúmọ̀ Ìtúnwí-ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́rọ̀ gan-an

english: We are going to be in the capital city’s streets for the whole month of February, on staggered days, 4 February was the beginning of the demonstrations, but on the 7th we will return to the streets, and again we will be there on the 11th and on the 13th we will hold a debriefing, if the government does not backtrack on the implementation of the presidential decree.
yoruba: A máa wà ní ojú òpópónà ní olú ìlú fún oṣù Èrèlé, ní àwọn ọjọ́ kọ̀ọ̀kan tí a yàn, ọjọ́ kẹrin oṣù Èrèlé ni ìwọ́de náà bẹ̀rẹ̀, àmọ́ ní ọjọ́ kéje ni a máa padà sí ojú òpópónà, tí a óò tún wà ní ọjọ́ kankànlá, tí a ó sì jábọ̀ ní ọjọ́ kẹtàlá, bí ìjọba kò bá yí ohùn padà.

english: Two young rappers, Lilo Kwanza and Adérito Gonçalves, made a song and video about this protest movement, with the title "Passport for 30 thousand", ironically commenting on the costs of the document to citizens.
yoruba: Àwọn akọrin ewì-alohùn ráàpù, Lilo Kwanza àti Adérito Gonçalves, kọ orin kan, tí wọ́n sì ya àwòrán-an orin tí ó dá lóríi ìwọ́de ìfẹ̀hónúhàn yìí, "Ìwé ẹ̀rí ọmọ-ìlú-fún-ìrìnnà 30,000" ni àkọlé orin náà, tí ó ń ṣe ẹ̀fẹ̀ lórí iye owó tabua tí ọmọ-ìlú yóò san fún ìwé ìrìnnà.

english: Days before the demonstration, the Angolan activist Pedrowski Teca said that the passport is more important than the identity card, asking people to join the protest:
yoruba: Ó ku ọjọ́ díẹ̀ kí ìwọ́de náà ó kò, ajàfúnẹ̀tọ́ ọmọ orílẹ̀-èdè Angola Pedrowski Teca sọ wípé ìwé ẹ̀rí ọmọ-ìlú-fún-ìrìnná pọn dandan ju ìwé ìdánimọ̀ pélébé lọ, ó rọ àwọn ènìyàn láti kọ́wọ̀ọ́ rìn, nítorí àìkọ́wọ̀ọ́ rìn, ní í ṣe ikú pa ọmọ ejò:

english: Translation Original Quote
yoruba: Ìtúmọ̀ Ìtúnwí-ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́rọ̀ gan-an

english: International demonstration against the absurd rise in the prices in Migration Acts.
yoruba: Àwọn àjọ àgbáyé ti dẹ̀yìn kọ Òfin Ìṣíkúrò tí ó pàṣẹ àfilé ìdíyelé tí ó gbéra nílẹ̀ fìrì tí ó sì lọ òkè lálá.

english: OBS: The identity card (B.I) only identifies an Angolan within national territory.
yoruba: OBS: Ìwé ìdánimọ̀ pélébé (B.I) wúlò gẹ́gẹ́ bí àmì ìdánimọ̀ ní àárín ìlú Angola.

english: Outside Angola, the identity card is useless, as the only valid identification document is a passport.
yoruba: Ní ẹ̀yìn odi ìlú Angola, pánda tí kò wúlò ni ìwé ìdánimọ̀ pélébé, kò sí àmì ìdánimọ̀ kan tí ó wà bí kò ṣe ìwé ẹ̀rí ọmọ-ìlú-fún-ìrìnnà.

english: We, inside the country, are going to protect and call on our compatriots in the diaspora to follow the same path, as the passport is more useful for them.
yoruba: Àwa, tí a wà nínú ìlú, ni a ó fi ààbò bò tí a ó sì ké pe àwọn aráa wa ní òkè òkun, kí àwọn náà ó ké gbàjarè, nítorí ìwé ẹ̀rí ọmọ-ìlú-fún-ìrìnnà ṣe kókó fún wọn.

english: To amplify the message, the activist and university student, David Mendes, wrote, on the day of the demonstration, a message for the Angolan president João Lourenço:
yoruba: Kí ìròyìn náà ó ba hó ye létí àwọn ènìyàn, ajàfúnẹ̀tọ́ọ nì àti akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ Ifáfitì, David Mendes, kọ, ní ọjọ́ ìwọ́de náà, iṣẹ́-ìjẹ́ fún ààre orílẹ̀-èdè Angola João Lourenço:

english: Translation Original Quote
yoruba: Ìtúmọ̀ Ìtúnwí-ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́rọ̀ gan-an

english: Comrade president João Lourenço, it was not for this that the Angolan people voted for you, in no moment of your campaigns did you spoke about a change of price of document, after all what are you thinking?
yoruba: Ọmọ-ẹgbẹ́ ààrẹ João Lourenço, kì í ṣe nítorí èyí ni àwọn aráa Angola ṣe yàn ọ́ sípò, kò sí ibi tí o ti sọ nínú ìpolongo ìléríi rẹ, o kò sọ pé ìwé ẹ̀rí yóò gbówó lórí, síbẹ̀ kí ni ò ń rò?

english: Where is the voice of the people?
yoruba: Kí ni ẹ fi ṣe ohùn àwọn mẹ̀kúnnù?

english: We already have a miserable life with these price rises, do you have an idea of the difficulty that you are causing for the people?
yoruba: A ti rí ìrora látàrí àwọn àfilé ìdíyelé, ǹjẹ́ o mọ ìṣòro tí ó ń fà fún àwọn ará ìlú?

english: We sincerely do not know who is the right man to govern our Angola, how will a youth who has no job find the money to get the documents?
yoruba: A kò tilẹ̀ mọ ẹni náà tí ó tọ́ láti tukọ̀ orílẹ̀-èdè Angola, báwo ni ọ̀dọ́ tí kò níṣẹ́ tí kò lábọ̀ yóò ṣe rí owó gba ìwé ẹ̀rí?

english: So far, the government has not reacted publicly, nor announced if it would consider reducing the price of passport.
yoruba: Pẹ̀lú gbogbo rẹ̀, ìjọba kò ì tíì sọ tó, tàbí kí ó kéde láti sọ bóyá òun yóò mú ìdíyelé náà wálẹ̀.

english: It's Emancipation Day in Trinidad & Tobago — but is the country free?
yoruba: Àyájọ́ Ọjọ́ Òmìnira ní Trinidad àti Tobago — àmọ́ ǹjẹ́ orílẹ̀-èdè náà ní òmìnira bí?

english: Citizens examine what stands in the way of true freedom
yoruba: Citizens examine what stands in the way of true freedom

english: Redemption Song Statue, Emancipation Park, Jamaica. Photo by Mark Franco, used with permission.
yoruba: Ère Orin Ìràpadà, Ọgbà Òmìnira, Jamaica. Àwòrán láti ọwọ́ọ Mark Franco, a gba àṣẹ láti lò ó.

english: August 1 is celebrated in many Caribbean territories as Emancipation Day, marking the freedom of enslaved Africans who were victims of the transatlantic slave trade.
yoruba: Ọjọ́ 1 oṣù Ògún ni ọ̀pọ̀ agbègbè tí ó wà ní Caribbean mọ̀ sí Àyájọ́ Ọjọ́ Òmìnira, tí í ṣe ọjọ́ tí a máa ń sààmi ìgbòmìnira àwọn ọmọ Adúláwọ̀ t'ó jìyà ní àsìkò okòwò ẹrú orí òkun atlantic.

english: Trinidad and Tobago was the first country in the world to declare a national holiday to mark the abolition of slavery, but 34 years after that first public holiday was instituted and 185 years after the Slavery Abolition Act first came into effect, great discussion continues over whether or not the twin-island republic is emancipated.
yoruba: Trinidad àti Tobago jẹ́ àkọ́kọ́ nínú àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè ní àgbáyé tí yóò ya ọjọ́ sọ́tọ̀ láti fi sọríi ìfòpin sí òwò ẹrú, àmọ́ lẹ́yìn-in 34 ọdún tí ìsinmi àpapọ̀ náà fi ẹsẹ̀múlẹ̀ àti ọdún 185 lẹ́yìn-in tí Àbá òfin Ìfòpin sówò-ẹrú kọ́kọ́ wáyé, awuyewuye ṣì ń lọ lóríi wípé bóyá erékùṣù-ìbejì olómìnira náà ní òmìnira tàbí kò ní.

english: Speaking about the issue on July 27, 2019, Prime Minister Dr. Keith Rowley observed that among Trinidad and Tobago's diverse population, people of African descent "are not doing as well as we expected".
yoruba: Nínú ọ̀rọ̀ọ rẹ̀ nípa òmìnira ní ọjọ́ 27, ọdún-un, Alákòóso Ìlú Dókítà. Keith Rowley ṣàkíyèsí wípé ní àárín àwọn ọmọ bíbíi Trinidad àti Tobago, àwọn tí ó jẹ́ ọmọ Adúláwọ̀ "kol ṣe dáadáa tó bí ó ṣe yẹ".

english: Rowley said that rising levels of violence which are part of the black, urban youth experience, should be inspiring citizens to "focus, reflect and have serious conversations about where we are as a nation".
yoruba: Rowley sọ wípé ìwà-ipá tí í ṣe ti ènìyàn dúdú, ìrírí ọ̀dọ̀, ní láti máa ṣe ìwúrí fún àwọn ọmọìlú láti "fiyèsí, ṣe àfihàn àti ṣe ìtàkùrọ̀sọ pàtàkì nípa ibi tí a wà gẹ́gẹ́ bí orílẹ̀-èdè".

english: Chairman of the country's Emancipation Support Committee, Khafra Khambon, agreed.
yoruba: Alága Ìgbìmọ̀ Àtìlẹ́yìn Òmìnira ti orílẹ̀-èdè náà, Khafra Khambon, gbà.

english: Some letters to the editor gave examples of modern slavery to make the point that true emancipation still seems a long way off, while others tried to make the occasion a political one, by criticising certain social services and a culture of “handouts.”
yoruba: Àwọn ìwé àpilẹ̀kọ kan sí olóòtú fi àwọn àpẹẹrẹ okòwò ẹrú ìgbàlódé láwùjọ hàn èyí tí ó fi hàn wípé òmìnira tòòtọ́ ṣì ku díẹ̀ káàtó, nígbà tí àwọn mìíràn gbìyànjú láti sọ ọ́ di ọ̀rọ̀ òṣèlú, bí wọ́n ṣe ń tako àwọn iṣẹ́ ìlú àti àṣà.

english: The Trinidad Express chose to feature an opinion on Emancipation Day which suggested that Rowley, Kambon, and activist Pearl Eintou Springer were wrong about why some Afro-Trinbagonians may be underperforming:
yoruba: Ìwé ìròyìn Trinidad Express yàn láti kọ èròo rẹ̀ nípa Àyájọ́ Ọjọ́ Òmìnira tí ó dábàá wípé Rowley, Kambon, àti ajàfẹ́tọ̀ọ́ ọmọ-ènìyàn Pearl Eintou Springer ṣì sọ nígbàtí wọ́n sọ ìdí tí àwọn ọmọìlú Trinidad àti Tobago tí ó jẹ́ ènìyàn dúdú ò fi ṣe dáadáa tó:

english: It is easy for a dominant group to create a system that discriminates and subjugates.
yoruba: Ó rọrùn fún ẹgbẹ́ tí ó dúró ṣinṣin láti dá ètòo ẹlẹ́yàmẹyà àti ìtẹ̀bọlẹ̀.

english: Those who do not measure up to that system are categorised as under-performers and relegated to second class or worse.
yoruba: Àwọn tí kò bá ètò náà lọ yóò di aláìṣetó tí wọ́n á sì di ẹni àgbésẹ́yìn sí ipò kejì tàbí èyí tí ó burú ju bẹ́ẹ̀ lọ.

english: So many of our systems, education the leader, put people unfairly in a caste and they are not given a second chance.
yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn ètòo wa, ẹ̀kọ́ tí í ṣe baba, ń gbé àwọn ènìyàn sí ipòo tálákà, kò sì fún wọn ní àǹfààní lẹ́ẹ̀kan sí i.

english: Every system has a rating and the further away it is from the top, the lower the ranking.
yoruba: Gbogbo ètò ni ó ní òṣùwọ̀n, tí ó ṣì jìnà gbégbérégbé sí òkè.

english: Those who find themselves on the bottom rung have great difficulty coping with the elevated systems.
yoruba: Àwọn tó bá ara wọn ní ìsàlẹ̀ ní ìṣòro láti bá àwọn tí ó wà ní òkè ṣe.

english: Self-esteem is low and in their perceived helplessness may even drive them to employ violence to counter-punch suppression.
yoruba: Iyì-ara-ẹni máa ń relẹ̀, tí èyí yóò sì mú wọn hu ìwà-ipá láti jà fún ẹ̀tọ́ọ wọn láwùjọ.

english: Commentator Arthur Dash lauded the country's “commendable history of maturity” when it comes to discussing race-related issues, but he also suggested the problem lay deeper, within the system itself, and suggested the prime minister's message should motivate citizens to examine how institutional racism continues to be a restrictive force.
yoruba: Ajábọ̀-ìròyín Arthur Dash gbóríyìn fún “ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀-àtẹ̀yìnwá ìdàgbàsókè” orílẹ̀-èdè náà ní ti ọ̀ràn-an ẹ̀yà, àmọ́ ó tún dá àbá wípé ìṣòro náà ju bí àwọn ti ṣe rò lọ, ó sì mú u ní àbá pé ó yẹ kí ọ̀rọ̀ alákòóso ìlú jẹ́ ìwúrí fún ọmọìlú láti ṣe ìwádìí fínnífínní sí bí ẹlẹ́yàmẹyà nínú ilé-iṣẹ ṣe ń pín àwọn ènìyàn sọ́tọ̀ọ̀tọ̀.

english: Social media users shared their musings as well. In a public post, Facebook user Adrian Raymond said:
yoruba: Àwọn òǹlò ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà sọ ti wọn. Òǹlò Facebook Adrian Raymond sọ:

english: On this day we remember and commemorate the freedom of our ancestors from the physical bondage of slavery.
yoruba: Ní ọjọ́ òní a ṣe ìrántí àti ìsààmì òmìnira àwọn babańláa wa nínú ìgbèkùn ara ti òwò ẹrú.

english: Today, many generations later, we the decendants [sic] of slaves struggle with the legacies left by colonialism.
yoruba: Ní òní, lẹ́yìn ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ọdún, àwa ọmọ ẹrú tí à ń jà fitafita fún àjogúnbá ìjọba amúnisìn.

english: Legacies which thrive and are perpetuated by stereotypes: We are not savage, we are not violent, we are not predators, we are not just thugs and gangsters.
yoruba: Àwọn àjogúnbá tí ó gbèèrú àti tí ó ní ìmúgbòrò ti di gbẹndẹ́kẹ: A ò kí ń ṣe òǹrorò, a ò kí ń ṣe oníjàgídíjàgan, a ò kí ń ṣe apanijẹ, a ò kàn kí ń ṣe ọ̀daràn àti ọmọ-ìta.

english: We are leaders, revolutionary thinkers, visionaries, philosophers.
yoruba: Olórí ni wa, aronújinlẹ̀ ni wa, ọlọ́pọlọ pípé ni wa, onímọ̀ ni wa.

english: We are Obama, Garvey, Marley, Angelou, Walcott.
yoruba: Obama ni wá, Garvey ni wa, Marley ni wa, Angelou ni wa, Walcott ni wa.

english: Let us recognize that colourism is an inherited tool used to divide us.
yoruba: Ẹ jẹ́ ká mọ̀ wípé ìyàsọ́tọ̀ọ̀tọ̀ nípa ti àwọ̀ ara ni ogún tí ó ń pín wa níyà.

english: Let us call out respectability politics: a culture of dilution; stop playing down blackness to make it palatable to the masses...
yoruba: Ẹ jẹ́ kí á ṣe ìṣèlú tó kún fún ọ̀wọ̀; ẹ dẹ́kun à ń ba dúdú jẹ́ ní etí àwọn ènìyàn...

english: Let us celebrate the rediscovery of our faith and belief systems.
yoruba: Ẹ jẹ́ ká ṣ’àjọyọ̀ àtúnrí àwọn ìgbàgbọ́ọ wa.

english: They took away the religion of our ancestors, they took away a belief system and sense of values.
yoruba: Wọ́n gba ẹ̀sìn àwọn babańláa wa, wọ́n mú ìgbàgbọ́ àti ohun iyìi wa kúrò ní ọkàn-an wa.

english: In today's world of information access you owe it to yourself to explore the belief systems of our ancestors, the reverence and honouring of the elders, the owning of one's actions an emphasis on choice and consequence, there is belief in the family, the extended family, the village, the community.
yoruba: Ní ayé òde òní tí ẹ̀rọ ayélujára mú iṣẹ́ ìwádìí rọrùn, ó yẹ kí o ṣe àyẹ̀wò sí ìgbàgbọ́ àwọn babańláa wa, ìbọ̀wọ̀ àti ìmọrírì àgbà, gbígba ìwùsàsí ẹni ìtẹnumọ́ ẹwùn àti èrè ìwà ẹni, ìgbàgbọ́ ń bẹ nínú ẹbí, nínúu mọ̀lẹ́bí, nínú ìletò, nínúu àdúgbó.

english: This emancipation embrace the fullness and richness of who you are, where you came from, the blood and history that's in your veins.
yoruba: Òmìnira yìí faramọ́ ẹni tí o jẹ́, ibi tí o ti ṣẹ̀ wá, ẹ̀jẹ̀ àti ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀-àtẹ̀yìwá tí ó wà nínú iṣan-ẹ̀jẹ̀.

english: Own with pride who you are, your culture, your identity.
yoruba: Gbá iyìi rẹ̀ mú, àṣàà rẹ, àti ìdánimọ̀ọ rẹ.

english: Bangladeshis use social media to tackle a dengue outbreak
yoruba: Àwọn ọmọ Bangladeshi lo ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà fi gbógun ti àjàkálẹ̀ àìsàn ibà-ẹ̀fọn

english: Many are resorting to social media to collect blood
yoruba: Ọ̀gọ̀rọ̀ l’ó ń d'orí kọ ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà lọ láti gba ẹ̀jẹ̀

english: Aedes albopictus mosquito, a carrier of Dengue fever.
yoruba: Ẹ̀fọn Aedes albopictus, tí ó máa ń gbé kòkòrò ibà ká.

english: Image via Wikipedia by James Gathany, CDC. Public Domain.
yoruba: Àwòrán láti oríi Wikipedia, James Gathany, CDC ni ó ni àwòrán, àwòrán Òde.

english: In the past few years, especially during the monsoon season, the number of dengue fever cases has risen in Bangladesh.
yoruba: Ní àárín ọdún, mélòó kan tí ó kọjá, pàápàá ní àsìkò ìjì ọdọọdún monsoon, iye àwọn tí àìsàn-an ibàa ẹ̀fọn ti kọlù ní Bangladeshì ti lékún síi.

english: This year, it took an alarming turn with a total of 7,179 cases recorded – nearly 2800 of them from the first half of July alone.
yoruba: Ní ọdún yìí, àwọn tí àìsàn-an ibàá kọlù tó bíi 7,179, àwọn - 2800 ní sáà kínní osùu Agẹmọ nìkan.

english: As government resources are seemingly overwhelmed by the severity of this recent spike in dengue cases, people are turning to social media to voice their complaints, share information about the spread of the virus, and to spread awareness about how people can protect themselves.
yoruba: Bí ètò ìjọba ò ṣe dántọ́ tó láti borí àjàkálẹ̀ àìsàn ibà tí ó gbòde yìí, àwọn ènìyàn ń gbẹ́kẹ̀le ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà láti fi sọ ẹ̀dùn-un ọkàn-an wọn, pín àlàyé nípa ìtànkálẹ̀ kòkòrò náà, àti ṣe ìkéde nípa bí àwọn ènìyán ṣe le dá ààbò bo ara wọn.

english: Record highs in July
yoruba: Àkọsílẹ̀ Àìsàn Pọ̀ Sí i Ní Osù Agẹmọ

english: 22 July saw record highs as 403 new dengue patients were admitted to hospitals in a 24-hour period.
yoruba: Ilé ìwòsàn gba àwọn aláìsàn ibà ẹ̀fọn 403 tí ó pọ̀ jù lọ ní ọjọ́ 22 osù Agẹmọ.

english: According to some experts, the effects of climate change, intermittent rain, unusual weather patterns, and lack of cleanliness are the main culprits for the rise in dengue cases.
yoruba: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí àwọn onímọ̀ kan ṣe rò, ipa ìyípadà ojú-ọjọ́, òjò àìdágbá kan, ojú-ọjọ́ tó ń ṣe ségesège, àti àìṣèmọ́tótó ni ọ̀dádá tí ó ń dá àtànkálẹ̀ ibà sílẹ̀.

english: Others also shared that this year's strain of the dengue virus is deadlier than in previous years. According to Twitter user Md. Saif:
yoruba: Àwọn mìíràn sọ wípé ibà ẹ̀fọn ti ọdún nìí ń ṣekú paon ju ti ẹ̀yìn wá lọ. Ní ti òǹlò Twitter Md. Saif:

english: "This year the strain and symptom of the disease have changed so you need to go to your doctor immediately after catching the fever" – according to an expert physician at the Bangabandhu Medical Hospital.
yoruba: "Ibà-ẹ̀fọn àti àmìi rẹ̀ ní ọdún yìí ti yàtọ̀ nítorí ìdí èyí ni o fi ní láti tọ oníṣègùn rẹ̀ lọ ní kété tí o bá ti ní ibà náà" – gẹ́gẹ́ bí ògbólògbó onímọ̀ ìlera ti Ilé-ìwòsàn Bangabandhu ti sọ.

english: Severely affected patients are having multiple organ failure – this was unheard of in the previous years.
yoruba: Àwọn ẹ̀yà ara àwọn aláìsàn tí amodi tẹ̀ ti ń daṣẹ́ sílẹ̀ – a kò gbọ́ èyí rí.

english: In an interview with the Bangla Tribune, Dr. Gulzar said that people who were previously infected with dengue have a greater risk of reinfection.
yoruba: Nínú ìfọ̀rọ̀wánilẹ́nuwò pẹ̀lú ìwé ìròyìn Bangla Tribune, Dókítà Gulzar sọ wípé kò sí bí a ṣe lè wo ibà ẹ̀fọn yìí nígbà àkọ́kọ́ tó, kí ó máà tún ṣeni lẹ́ẹ̀ẹkejì.

english: Translation Original Quote
yoruba: Ìtúmọ̀ Ìtúnwí-ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́rọ̀ gan-an

english: This year Dengue has a new strain, deadlier.
yoruba: Ibà-ẹ̀fọn ti ọdún yìí jẹ́ tuntun, ó sì yára pa ènìyàn.

english: It is inducing Dengue shock syndrome.
yoruba: Ó sì ń fa àmì ìfòyà.

english: There may be another cause – many were infected in the previous years, many perhaps did not notice.
yoruba: Ohun tí ó lè fà á lè pọ̀ – ọ̀pọ̀ ni ó kó àìsàn ní ọdún tí ó kọjá, tí wọn kò fura.

english: When they are being infected the second time, it is becoming deadlier.
yoruba: Bí ó bá tún tẹ̀ wọ́n ní ẹ̀rìn kejì, sààárè ń sún mọ́ nìyẹn.

english: Reports about new infection cases are spreading on social media and many users are becoming increasingly worried.
yoruba: Ìròyìn nípa àjàkálẹ̀ àìsàn yìí ń gba gbogbo orí ẹrọ-alátagbà kan tí ó sì ń mú àìbalẹ̀ara àti ọkàn bá ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn òǹlo ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà.

english: Shofiq Ahmed shared a Tweet about a newly reported case:
yoruba: Shofiq Ahmed pín Túwíìtì kan nípa ìròyìn àìsàn tuntun:

english: Even two doctors died in Dengue fever, and people are afraid now.
yoruba: Àwọn dókítà méjì kan náà kú látàrí ibà-ẹ̀fọn, èyí sì ti ń mú kí àwọn ènìyàn ó máa bẹ̀rù.

english: The Dhaka Highcourt has summoned the Chief Health Officers of the government.
yoruba: Ilé-ẹjọ́ Gíga Dhaka ti fi àṣẹ pe Ọ̀gá Àgbà Ètò Ìlera ti ìjọba.

english: The death toll is incereasing.
yoruba: Àwọn tí ó ń kú nh pọ̀ ọ́ sí i.

english: Is the government doing enough?
yoruba: Ǹjẹ́ ìjọbá ń ṣe tó?

english: BBC Bangla Facebook page asked its readers to report back about any efforts by city officials in Dhaka to combat the spread the mosquitos.
yoruba: Ojú-ìwé Facebook ti BBC Bangla rọ àwọn òǹkàwée rẹ̀ láti jábọ̀ àwọn ìgbésẹ̀ akin tí àwọn òníṣẹ́ ìlú Dhaka ń gbé láti gbógun ti ẹ̀fọn.

english: User Mohammad Mynuddin reported astonishing delays on the part of government officials to address the outbreak:
yoruba: Òǹlò Mohammad Mynuddin jábọ̀ ìfàsẹ́yìn láti ọwọ́ àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ ìjọba láti kápá àjàkálẹ̀ náà:

english: Nothing has been seen.
yoruba: A ò tíì rí nǹkan.

english: A (City Corporation) worker has said that it would take a few weeks to import the protective drugs to decrease mosquitoes.
yoruba: Òṣìṣẹ́ Àjọ Ìlú kan ti sọ wípé yóò tó ọ̀sẹ̀ mélòó kan kí egbògi ìdáààbòbò tí yó sì dín ẹ̀fọn kù.

english: I was astonished 🤔🤔
yoruba: Ó yà mí lẹ́nu 🤔🤔

english: With what many see as a lack of government response to the spike in dengue cases, citizens are taking to social media to raise awareness about the virus.
yoruba: Àwọn kan lérò wípé ìjọba ò mú kiní ibà-ẹ̀fọn ọ̀hún ní kanpá, àwọn ọmọìlú ń lo ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà mú kí àwọn ènìyàn ó mọ̀ nípa kòkòrò náà.

english: Citizen media news outlet Health Barta uploaded a YouTube video detailing what to do when someone has dengue fever:
yoruba: Health Barta gbé fídíò kan sí oríi YouTube tí ó ń ṣe àlàyé lẹ́kùnúnrẹ́rẹ́ ohun tí ó pọn dandan láti ṣe bí èèyán bá ní ibà-ẹ̀fọn:

english: Many are resorting to social media to collect blood for patients.
yoruba: Ọ̀gọ̀rọ̀ l’ó ń d'orí kọ ẹ̀rọ-alátagbà lọ láti gba ẹ̀jẹ̀ fún àwọn aláìsàn.

english: User Sajid Islam Khan tweeted that he needs blood for his brother who is suffering from dengue.
yoruba: Òǹlo Sajid Islam Khan túwíìtì pé òún nílò ẹ̀jẹ̀ fún àbúrò òun tí ibà-ẹ̀fọn ń bá fínra.

english: Hannan Gazi posted a similar message:
yoruba: Hannan Gazi náà se àgbéjáde tirẹ̀:

english: The symptoms of dengue fevere and what to do..
yoruba: Àmì ibà-ẹ̀fọn àti àtiṣe..

english: Amidst the outbreak, the Mayor of Dhaka City North has canceled holiday leave for waste disposal and mosquito deterrent teams.
yoruba: Ní àárín-in àjàkálẹ̀ náà, Alákòóso-ìlú Àríwá Dhaka ti fagilé ìsinmi ránpẹ́ àwọn ikọ̀ tí ó ń rí sí pàntí kíkó àti ìgbégidínà àpọ̀si ẹ̀fọn.

english: However, to protect people from dengue fever, a lot more effort may be needed.
yoruba: Síbẹ̀síbẹ̀, fún ìdáààbò àwọn ènìyàn, ṣíṣe ṣì kú.

english: Demolition of a 150-year-old building highlights government neglect of Bangladesh's heritage sites
yoruba: Àdàwólulẹ̀ ilé ayé-àtijọ́ ọlọ́dún-un 150 fi àìkáràmáìsìkí ìjọba sí àwọn ibi àjogúnbáa Bangladesh hàn

english: The landmark building was demolished despite a High Court Directive
yoruba: Ilé àjogúnbá náà di àwópalẹ̀ pẹ̀lú bí Ilé-ẹjọ́ Gíga ṣe pa àṣẹ.

english: The dilapidated state of “Jahaj Bari” before being demolished.
yoruba: Ẹgẹrẹmìtì “Jahaj Bari” kí ó tó di àdàwólulẹ̀.

english: It was the first commercial house in the Bangladeshi capital, Dhaka, built in 1870. Image by Shakil Ahmed, used with permission.
yoruba: Òun ni ilé àkọ́kọ́ àyàgbé ní olú-ìlú Bangladeshi, Dhaka, a kọ́ ọ ní ọdún-un 1870. Àwòrán láti ọwọ́ọ Shakil Ahmed, a fi àṣẹ lò ó.

english: In Dhaka, a century-old heritage building was demolished clandestinely on the night of Eid-ul-Fitr on June 5, 2019.
yoruba: Ní Dhaka, ilé àjogúnbá ọlọ́gọ́rùn-ún ọdún kan di àdàwólulẹ̀ pátá ní alẹ́ ọjọ́ Ìtunu Àwẹ̀ 5, oṣù Òkúdù 2019.

english: The ship-like structure, known locally as "Jahaj Bari", was built around 1870 and considered to be the first commercial building in Bangladesh's capital.
yoruba: Ní nǹkan bíi ọdún-un 1870 ni a kọ́ ilé náà tí ó fẹ́ẹ́ dà bíi ọkọ̀ ojú-omi, tí àwọn ọmọ ìbílẹ̀ ń pè ní "Jahaj Bari", òun sì ni ilé àyágbé àkọ́kọ́ ni olú-ìlúu Bangladesh.

english: Its demolition has caused many to speak out against the neglect of Dhaka's architectural treasures.
yoruba: Àdàwólulẹ̀ tí a da ilé yìí ti mú kí àwọn ọ̀pọ̀ ènìyàn ó sọ ẹ̀dùn ọkàn-an wọn síta lórí àìbìkítà fún àwọn ilé tí ó jẹ́ ohun ìṣúra Dhaka.

english: Media reports alleged that supporters of the ruling Awami League (AL) party brought three bulldozers to the location and demolished the building.
yoruba: Ìròyìn fi yé wípé àwọn ọmọ ẹgbẹ́ òṣèlú tí ó wà lórí ipò ìyẹn Awami League (AL) gbé ẹ̀rọ tatapùpù wá sí ibẹ̀, wọ́n sì da ilé náà wó.

english: The supporters claim that their leader, local member of parliament (Dhaka-7) Haji Md. Salim, bought the property to build a multi-story building on the site.
yoruba: Àwọn tí ó wá ṣiṣẹ́ náà sọ wípé olóríi àwọn, ọmọ ìgbìmọ̀ ìbílẹ̀ (Dhaka-7) Haji Md. Salim, ti ra ilẹ̀ náà láti fi kọ́ ilé alájà tó pọ̀ sí ibùdó náà.

english: The AL supporters also claimed that the building was not included on any heritage list.
yoruba: Bákan náà àwọn alátìlẹ́yìn AL sọ wípé ilé àtijọ́ náà kò sí lóríi àwọn ibi àjogúnbá tí ó wà nínú àkọsílẹ̀.

english: On August 13, 2018, the Dhaka High Court issued a directive to the government agency responsible for coordinating urban development in Dhaka to not approve or allow the demolition or modification of 2,200 archaeologically significant buildings around the capital city.
yoruba: Ní ọjọ́ 13, oṣù Ògún ọdún-un 2018, Ilé-ẹjọ́ Gíga Dhaka pàṣẹ fún àjọ ìjọba tí ó ń rí sí ètò ìdàgbàsókè ìlú ní ìlànà tìgbàlódé ní Dhaka láti máà wó tàbí tún àwọn ilé àjogúnbá tí ó wà ní olú-ìlú náà tó bíi 2,200 kọ́.

english: Jahaj Bari is also part of a Waqf (mortmain) estate that, as part of a charitable donation, could not be sold.
yoruba: Jahaj Bari wà nínú àwọn ilé àkọ́pọ̀ Waqf (mortmain) tí kò ṣe é tà.

english: According to the administrator of Bangladesh's Waqf Administration, it is mandatory to have permission in order to hand over, sell or develop any Waqf property.
yoruba: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí alákòóso Bangladesh Waqf Administratioń ṣe sọ, gbígba àṣẹ pọn dandan láti gbé iṣẹ́ sílẹ̀, tà tàbí ṣe àtúnṣe sí ohunkóhun tí ó bá jẹ́ ti Waqf.

english: Contrary to the claims of the AL activists, no such permission was requested for the sale or demolition of the building in question.
yoruba: Èyí kò rí bí ajàfẹ́tọ̀ọ́ AL náà ti ṣe wí, kò sí ohun tó jọ ọ́, kò sí àṣẹ tí ó ní kí wọ́n tà tàbí wó ilé tí à ń sọ̀rọ̀ọ rẹ̀ yìí.

english: In March 2019, an attempt was made to demolish the building.
yoruba: Nínú oṣùu Ẹrẹ́nà ọdún-un 2019, a gbé ìgbésẹ̀ kan láti da ilé náà wó lulẹ̀.

english: Urban Study Group, a volunteer-run nonprofit group dedicated to protecting the historical urban fabric of Old Dhaka, filed a complaint to stop the demolition, citing the above mentioned High Court order.
yoruba: Urban Study Group, ẹgbẹ́ aṣiṣẹ́ ọ̀fẹ́-tí-kò-ní-èrè tí ó máa ń fi ààbò fún àwọn ohun àjogúnbá Dhaka Àtijọ́ fi ìwé ẹ̀dùn ìdáwọ́dúróo àdàwólulẹ̀ náà ránṣẹ́ sí àwọn tí ọ̀rán kàn, tí ó sì mẹ́nu ba àṣẹ Ilé-ẹjọ́ Gíga.

english: However, according to newspaper reports, some locals are happy that the building was demolished.
yoruba: Síbẹ̀, bí ìwé ìròyìn ṣe jábọ̀, díẹ̀ lára àwọn ọmọ ìbílẹ̀ ń yọ̀ fún àdàwólulẹ̀ ilé náà.

english: They felt that it was in a dilapidated state and feared that it would fall down on them—an indication of the lack of awareness of historical preservation and support for the restoration of heritage buildings in Bangladesh.
yoruba: Wọ́n ò mọ̀ pé ilé náà ti di ẹgẹrẹmìtì, ó sì lè wò lulẹ̀ kí ó wó lù wọ́n—tí í ṣe àpẹẹrẹ àìmọ̀kanmọ̀kàn àwọn ènìyàn sí ìpamọ́ ohun àjogúnbá àti àtìlẹ́yìn fún àtúnṣe sí ilé àtijọ́ tí ó wà ní Bangladesh.

english: Heritage history—just empty words
yoruba: Àjogúnbá Ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ Àtẹ̀yìnwá —ọ̀rọ̀ tí ò jẹ́ mọ́ nǹkan

english: Many expressed their anger on hearing about the destruction of the building.
yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀ ènìyàn l'ó fi ẹ̀dùn ọkàn-an wọn hàn nígbà tí wọ́n gbọ́ nípa àmúdipẹ̀tẹ́lẹ̀ ilé náà.

english: Shuvra Kar wrote on Facebook:
yoruba: Shuvra Kar kọ sí oríi Facebook:

english: Translation Original Quote
yoruba: Ìtúmọ̀ Ìtúnwí-ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́rọ̀ gan-an

english: Heritage, history, culture these are just empty words in this country!
yoruba: Àjogúnbá , ìtàn-ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀-àtẹ̀yìnwá, àṣá jẹ́ ọ̀rọ̀ tí kò já mọ́ nǹkan ní orílẹ̀-èdè yìí!

english: Writer Tania Kamrun Nahar explained why this heritage building needed to be saved:
yoruba: Òǹkọ̀wé Tania Kamrun Nahar tan ìmọ́lẹ̀ sí ìdí tí kò fi yẹ kí ilé yìí di àdàwólulẹ̀:

english: Translation Original Quote
yoruba: Ìtúmọ̀ Ìtúnwí-ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́rọ̀ gan-an

english: The three-storied "Jahaj Bari" had beautiful motifs on the railings.
yoruba: Ilé alájà-mẹ́ta náà “Jahaj Bari” ní àwọn iṣẹ́ ọnà tí ó yàrà ọ̀tọ̀ lára ní ara irin àgbọ́wọ́lé gun àkàsọ̀ .

english: The long verandah had designed roofs.
yoruba: Iṣẹ́ ọnà aláràbarà ti orí òrùlé ibi ìbojúwòta gígùn.

english: The whole building had many beautiful designs — pointed arches, decorated cornices.
yoruba: Ọ̀kanòjọ̀kan ọnà ni ó wà ní ara ilé náà — àwọn àràbarà ọnà abẹ́ àjà àti bẹ́ẹ̀ bẹ́ẹ̀ lọ.

english: The columns had ionic and Corinthian capital designs.
yoruba: Àwọn òpó ní àwòṣe ọnà ilée ionic àti Corinthian.

english: The building had such remarkable designs which were rare to find in other buildings in the old parts of Dhaka.
yoruba: Ọnà ara ilé náà kọjá àfẹnusọ tí a kò le è rí lára àwọn ilé mìíràn ní àwọn agbègbè àtijọ́ọ Dhaka.

english: So, the building needed to be saved.
yoruba: Fún ìdí èyí, kò yẹ kí ilé náà di àdàwólulẹ̀.

english: Dhaka was established as the capital of Bengal in 1610, more than four centuries ago.
yoruba: Ọdún-un 1610 ni Dhaka di olú-ìlúu Bengal, ìyẹn ogójì ọdún sẹ́yìn.

english: During the years of Mughal rule and British colonial rule, many buildings were built that form part of the history and heritage of the city.
yoruba: Ní sáàa Mughal àti ìjọba amúnisìn British, ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ilé tí a kọ́ ni ó ní ìtàn-ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀-àtẹ̀yìnwá àti àjogúnbá ìlú náà kan tí ó rọ̀ mọ́ ọn.

english: But most of these buildings are long gone.
yoruba: Àmọ́ púpọ̀ nínú àwọn ilé wọ̀nyí ni ó ti wó láti ọjọ́ pípẹ́.

english: The ones that remain are in a dilapidated state and are destined to be grabbed by occupants claiming ownership of the buildings (often by forging documents).
yoruba: Àwọn tí ó ṣì ń dúró ti di ẹgẹrẹmìtì, èyí á mú kí àwọn kan ó máa lọ (ṣe ayédèrú ìwé láti) gbẹ́sẹ̀ lé ilé wọ̀nyí.

english: One example is Bara Katra, a historical and architectural monument built between 1644 and 1646 AD by Mir Abul Qasim, the Diwan (chief revenue official) of the Mughal prince Shah Shuja.
yoruba: Àpẹẹrẹ kan ni Bara Katra, àrágbáramúramù ilé tí ó ní ìtàn-ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀-àtẹ̀yìnwá tí Mir Abul Qasim, Diwan (alága ètò ìṣúná) ti ó jẹ́ ọmọba Shah Shuja Mughul kọ́ ní nǹkan bíi 1644 àti 1646.

english: The building is on the verge of collapsee due to the lack of maintenance, preservation efforts, and damage caused by illegal occupants.
yoruba: Ó jẹ́ nǹkan ìbànújẹ́ wípé ilé náà ti ṣe tán, ó lè wó nígbàkigbà látorí àìṣàtúnṣe, àìkáràmáìsìkí ohun àjogúnbá, àti ìbàjẹ́ tí àwọn tí ó gbé ilé láì gba àṣẹ ń fà.

english: Bara Katra, the structure was built according to the traditional pattern of Central Asian caravanserais and is embellished in the style of Mughal architecture.
yoruba: Bara Katra, àwòṣe ilé kíkọ́ ìbílẹ̀ Àárín gbùngbùn Asian caravanserais ni a fi kọ́ ọ, ó sì ní ọwọ́ọ àwòṣe Mughal náà.

english: Image by Ragib Hassan via Wikipedia. CC BY 2.5
yoruba: Ragib Hassan ni ó ní àwòrán ní oríi Wikipedia. CC BY 2.5

english: Muntasir Mamun has written many books on the history and heritage of Dhaka city.
yoruba: Muntasir Mamun ti kọ àìmọye ìwé lóríi ìtàn-ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀-àtẹ̀yìnwá àti àjogúnbá ìlúu Dhaka.

english: He wrote in a local newspaper Bhorer Kagoj:
yoruba: Ó kọ sínú ìwé ìròyìn ìbílẹ̀ẹ Bhorer Kagoj:

english: Translation Original Quote
yoruba: Ìtúmọ̀ Ìtúnwí-ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́rọ̀ gan-an

english: I have pleaded to the authorities in the past four decades to save the heritage buildings like Bara Katra and Choto Katra.
yoruba: Mo ti rawọ́ ẹ̀bẹ̀ sí àwọn aláṣẹ fún ogójì ọdún tí ó kọjá láti gba àwọn ilé àjogúnbá bíi Bara Katra àti Choto Katra sílẹ̀ lọ́wọ́ àwọn tí ó fẹ́ pa ìtàn àtẹ̀yìnwá rẹ́.

english: But nobody listened.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n kò sí ẹni tí ó dá mi lóhùn.

english: When the philatelic department demolished part of the old walls of the famous Lalbagh Fort to make a car park, what can you say?
yoruba: Kí ni ká sọ? Nígbà tí ẹ̀ka tí ó ń ṣe àkópamọ́ sítám̀pù ti wo ògiri àtijọ́ àmọ̀káyée Lalbagh Fort láti fi ṣe àyè ìgbọ́kọ̀sí.

english: How can you fight against stupidity?
yoruba: Báwo ni a ó ṣe dojú ìjà kọ ìwà òmùgọ̀?

english: An online news portal has published an in-depth report about government negligence of these heritage buildings and the influential people trying to demolish existing buildings:
yoruba: Ilé oníròyìn orí-ayélujára kan ti ṣe àtẹ̀jáde àbájáde ìwádìí tí ó jinlẹ̀ nípa àìkáràmáìsìkí ìjọba lóríi àwọn ilé àjogúnbá àti àwọn alẹ́nulọ́rọ̀ tí ó ń gbìyànjú láti da àwọn ilé tí ó kù wó:

english: Translation Original Quote
yoruba: Ìtúmọ̀ Ìtúnwí-ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́rọ̀ gan-an

english: The no. 14 house in the heritage list has already been taken down.
yoruba: Ilé tí ó wà ní ipò.14 ní orí ìwé àkọsílẹ̀ àjogúnbá ti di wíwó.

english: Most parts of the famous big house in Sutrapur has been destroyed.
yoruba: Apá kan lára àwọn ilé àwòṣífìlà tí ó wà ní Sutrapur kò ṣe é rí mọ́n.

english: The relics of the Mughal era in Bangshal Mukim Bazar Jam-e Mosque and Siddique Bazar Jam-e Mosque are gone with a new structure in place in the name of renovation.
yoruba: Iṣẹ́ àtúnṣe sí àwọn àjogúnbá ìgbàa Mughal ní mọ́ṣálááṣí Bangshal Mukim Bazar Jam-e àti mọ́ṣálááṣí Siddique Bazar Jam-e ti di ohun ìgbàgbé nítorí ojú àpá ò le è jọ ojú ara, ó ti yàtọ̀.

english: Although there is a government directive to protect heritage buildings, the officials of Rajdhani Unnayan Kartripakkha and Dhaka City Corporation are not doing anything.
yoruba: Àmọ́ ṣá, ó ní àṣẹ ìjọba tí ó fi ààbò bo àwọn ilé àjogúnbá, àwọn agbèfúnjọba ti agbègbèe Rajdhani Unnayan Kartripakkha àti Àjọ Ìlúu Dhaka kò ṣe ohun tí ó yẹ kí wọn ó ṣe.

english: Their inaction is encouraging greedy parties to grab the old properties and destroy them.
yoruba: Àìṣojúṣe wọn ni ó fà á tí àwọn olóṣèlú olójúkòkòrò ṣe ń gba àwọn ilé àtijọ́ tí wọ́n sì ń dà wọ́n wó lulẹ̀.

english: The Urban Study Group has organized rallies and human chains to protest these demolitions.
yoruba: Ẹgbẹ́ Urban Study ti ṣe àgbékalẹ̀ ìwọ́de àti àkójọ àwọn ènìyàn tí yóò fi ẹ̀hónú àdàwólulẹ̀ wọ̀nyí hàn.

english: They are also keen to create awareness to protect other endangered heritage buildings.
yoruba: Bẹ́ẹ̀ náà ni wọ́n gbèrò láti ṣe ìkéde nípa ìdààbò bo àwọn ilé àjogúnbá tí ọ̀rán kàn.

english: Here are some more images of Bangladeshi heritage buildings in peril:
yoruba: Àwòrán ìsàlẹ̀ yìí ni àwọn ilé àjogúnbáa Bangladeshi tí àdàwólulẹ̀ ń bá:

english: An old Zamindar house in Nazira Bazar of Old Dhaka is being demolished. Image by Shakil Ahmed. Used with permission.
yoruba: Ilée Zamindar àtijọ́ kan ní Nazira Bazar ní agbègbèe Àtijọ́ọ Dhaka ti ń di wíwó lulẹ̀. Àwòrán láti ọwọ́ọ Shakil Ahmed. A lò ó pẹlú àṣẹ.

english: Nimtali Palace, it was the residence of the Deputy Governor of Dhaka during the Mughal rule.
yoruba: Aàfin Nimtali, òun ni ibùgbé Gómìnà Dhaka ní ayée Ìjọba Mughal.

english: Only the west gate of the palace still survives.
yoruba: Ìloro àbáwọlé ìwọ̀-oòrùn-un ààfin náà nìkan ló ṣì ń dúró.

english: Image by Shakil Ahmed, used with permission.
yoruba: Àwòrán láti ọwọ́ọ Shakil Ahmed, a lò ó pẹlú àṣẹ.

english: ShankhaNidhi House This is another century-old building in Dhaka.
yoruba: ShankhaNidh Èyí ni ilé ọgọ́rùn-ún ọdún sẹ́yìn mìíràn ní Dhaka.

english: Without preservation, this building is barely surviving.
yoruba: Láìsí àmójútó, ilé yìí ṣì dúró.

english: Image by Shakil Ahmed, used with permission.
yoruba: Àwòrán láti ọwọ́ọ Shakil Ahmed. A lò ó pẹlú àṣẹ.

english: Northbrook Hall or Lal Kuthi – photographed in 1904 by Fritz Kapp.
yoruba: Northbrook Hall tàbí Lal Kuthi – Fritz Kapp ni ó ya àwòrán yìí ní ọdún-un 1904.

english: This building is barely surviving now.
yoruba: Ilé yìí ṣì ń dúró lónìí.

english: Image via Wikipedia. Public Domain
yoruba: Oríi Wikipedia ni àwòrán yìí wà. Ojú Òde

english: China arrests filmmaker for retweeting an image of a liquor bottle referencing Tiananmen Massacre
yoruba: China fi ọwọ́ọ ṣìnkún òfin mú ayàwòrán eré orí ìtàgé nítorí pé ó tún àwòrán ìgò ọtí-líle kan tí ó ń tọ́ka sí Ìpanìyànnípakúpa Tiananmen pín

english: Baijiu bottles commemorating the Tiananmen massacre.
yoruba: Àwọn ìgòo Baijiu ń ṣe ìrántí ìpànìyànnípakúpa Tiananmen náà.

english: The following post is originally written by Jennifer Creery and published by Hong Kong Free Press on May 24, 2019.
yoruba: Jennifer Creery ni ẹni tí ó kọ ìròyìn yìí, tí Ilé Iṣẹ́ Atẹ̀wé Olómìnira Hong Kong sì tẹ̀ ẹ́ jáde ní ọjọ́ 24 oṣù Èbìbí ọdún-un 2019.

english: The following edited version is republished on Global Voices under a content partnership agreement.
yoruba: Ohùn Àgbáyé ṣe ẹ̀dàa ìròyìn náà ní abẹ́ ìtọwọ́bọ̀wé àjọṣe pọ̀ ìkóròyìnjọ.

english: Chinese authorities have reportedly detained documentary filmmaker Deng Chuanbin after he tweeted an image of a liquor bottle labelled "64" – a reference to the date of the Tiananmen Square Massacre which occurred on June 4, 1989.
yoruba: Àwọn aláṣẹ ìjọba China ti fi ayàwòrán eré aṣakọ̀sílẹ̀-ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ Deng Chuanbin sí àtìmọ́lé lẹ́yìn tí ó ṣe túwíìtì àwòrán ìgò ọtí-líle kan tí a sààmìi "64" sí lára – tí ó ń tọ́ka sí ọjọ́ burúkú Èṣù gbomi mu Ìpaninípakúpa tí ó wáyé ní Tiananmen Square ní ọjọ́ 4, oṣù Òkúdù ọdún-un 1989.

english: 64 liquor bottle
yoruba: Ìgò ọtí-líle 64

english: The liquor bottle was designed in 2016 to commemorate the 27th anniversary of June 4.
yoruba: Ọdún-un 2016 ni a ṣe ìgòo ọtí-líle náà, ìyẹn ní ìrántí ọdún kẹtàdínlọ́gbọ̀n tí ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ láabi ọjọ́ 4 oṣù Òkúdù wáyé.

english: The liquor was called "8 wine 64".
yoruba: Orúkọ tí a pe ọtí-líle náà ni "8 wine 64".

english: The pronunciation of the word "wine" in Putonghua is the same with the word "9".
yoruba: Bí a ti ṣe ń pe "wine" ní èdèe Putonghua náà ni à ń pe "9".

english: The bottle label carries the image of "Tank Man" with the description "Never forget, never give up".
yoruba: Ààmì ara ìgò náà ní àwòrán "Ọkùnrin ọkọ̀-ogun" tí a kọ "Máà ṣe gbàgbé, máà ṣe sọ̀rètí nù".

english: It also specifies that the wine comes from Beijing, with 64% alcohol and has been stored for 27 years.
yoruba: Ó sì tún fi han gbangbagbàngbà pé Beijing ni a ti ṣe ọtíi wáìnì náà tí ó ní ìdá 64 iye ọtí-líle nínú tí ó sì ti wà nílé ìtajà fún ọdún mẹ́tadínlọ́gbọ̀n.

english: Four Chinese men, Fu Hailu, Zhang Jinyong, Luo Fuyu and Chen Bing, were arrested in 2016 for the liquor bottle incident charged with "inciting subversion of state power".
yoruba: A fi ọwọ́ọ ṣìnkún òfin mú àwọn ọmọkùnrin orílẹ̀ èdèe China mẹ́rin, Fu Hailu, Zhang Jinyong, Luo Fuyu àti Chen Bing, ní ọdún-un 2016 fún ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ ìgò ọtí-líle tí a sì fi ẹ̀sùn-un “rírú ìṣẹ́po agbáraiìlú sókè”.

english: Fu, Zhang and Luo's trial took place at the Chengdu Intermediate People’s Court in April.
yoruba: Ìgbẹ́jọ́ Fu, Zhang àti Luo's wáyé ní ibìkan ní Ilé-ẹjọ́ Àwọn Ènìyàn Agbedeméjì Chengdu nínú oṣù Igbe.

english: They were respectively handed a three-year prison term with four to five years in suspension.
yoruba: Ọ̀kọ̀ọ̀kan wọn gba ìdájọ́ ìgbà ọdún mẹ́ta ní ẹ̀wọ̀n pẹ̀lú ìdádúró ọdún mẹ́rin sí márùn-ún.

english: Chen is still under arrest as he refused to plead guilty.
yoruba: Nítorí pé Chen kò gbà wípé òun dá ẹ̀ṣẹ̀, ó sì wà lábẹ́ẹ ṣìgún òfin.

english: Despite the suspended sentence, the three are still under surveillance:
yoruba: Pẹ̀lú ìdádúró ìránlẹ́wọ̀n, àwọn mẹ́tẹ̀ẹ̀ta ṣì wà lábẹ́ ìṣọ́:

english: Arrest for a retweet
yoruba: Ìfọwọ́ọ ṣìnkún òfin múni nítorí àtúnpín túwíìtì

english: Ahead of the 30th anniversary of June 4, filmmaker Deng Chuabin has become the latest victim related to the 64 liquor bottle.
yoruba: Ní ìpalẹ̀mọ́ ìsààmì ọgbọ̀n ọdún tí ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ ọjọ́ 4, ayàwòrán eré orí ìtàgé Deng Chuabin ti di ẹni tí ọ̀rọ̀ ìgò ọtí-líle 64 ń dá sẹ̀ríà fún lọ́wọ́lọ́wọ́.

english: Sichuan police arrested Deng at his home in Yibin last Friday, hours after he retweeted a Twitter photo of 64 liquor bottle, according to the NGO coalition, Chinese Human Rights Defenders (CHRD).
yoruba: Ọlọ́pàá Sichuan fi ọwọ́ọ ṣìgún òfin mú Deng ní ilée rẹ̀ ní Yibin ní ọjọ́ Ẹtì tí ó kọjá, lẹ́yìn wákàtí díẹ̀ tí ó ṣe àtúnpín àwòrán-an Twitter kan tí ó jẹ́ ti ìgò ọtí-líle 64, gẹ́gẹ́ bí Iléeṣẹ́-tí-kìí-ṣe-tìjọba, Adáààbòbo Ẹ̀tọ́ Ọmọ ènìyàn ti China (CHRD).

english: The filmmaker received a phone call from police 30 minutes after tweeting the image despite quickly deleting the post, said CHRD.
yoruba: Ayàwòrán náà gba ìpè àwọn ọlọ́pàá lẹ́yìn-in ọgbọ̀n ìṣẹ́jú lẹ́yìn tí ó túwíìtì àwòrán náà pẹ̀lú wípé lẹ́sẹ̀kẹsẹ̀ ni ó mú un wálẹ̀, bẹ́ẹ̀ ni CHRD ṣe ti sọ.

english: Police seized three mobile phones, a computer, laptop, iPad, memory cards and compact camera while at his home.
yoruba: Àwọn ọlọ́pàá fi agbára gba ẹ̀rọ ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ alágbèéká mẹ́ta, ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣá kọ̀mpútà kan, ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣá àgbélétan kan, iPad, ike pélébé ìrántí àti ẹ̀rọ ayàwòrán kékeré kan nígbà tí wọ́n wá sí ilée rẹ̀.

english: Deng is reportedly being held in Nanxi District Detention Centre for "picking quarrels" – a charge frequently leveled against critics of the government.
yoruba: Deng ti wà ní Àtìmọ́lé Agbègbè Nanxi nítorí wípé “ó ń bá ìjà bọ̀” – ẹ̀sùn tí wọ́n sábà máa ń kà mọ́ àwọn ènìyàn tí ó ń takò ìjọba lẹ́sẹ̀.

english: CHRD said police returned to raid Deng’s home for an hour, taking a range of electronic equipment:
yoruba: CHRD sọ wípé fún wákàtí kan gbáko, àwọn ọlọ́pàá padà láti yẹ ilée Deng wò, wọ́n sì kó àwọn ẹ̀rọ lóríṣiríṣi:

english: 18 people are talking about this
yoruba: 18 people are talking about this

english: Update on #Deng Chuabin: On May 20, 2019: Deng's father was summoned to the police station at Peizhi town.
yoruba: Ọ̀rọ̀ tí ó ń lọ nípa #Deng Chuabin: Ní ọjọ́ 20 oṣù Èbìbì ọdún-un 2019: Àwọn ọlọ́pàá àgọ́ọ Peizhi ránṣẹ́ sí bàbáa Deng.

english: A few men followed him back home and took video and photos in their house.
yoruba: Àwọn kan tẹ̀lée padà sílé, wọ́n sì ya àwòrán nínú ilée wọn.

english: They search Deng Chuabin's room for more than an hour and took away 20 electronic items including battery chargers.
yoruba: Wọ́n tú yàráa Deng Chuabin wò fún bíi wákàtí kan, wọ́n sì gbé ẹ̀rọ 20 àti agbaná sí ara ẹ̀rọ.

english: They even took away the electronic wire of their rice cooker.
yoruba: Wọ́n tún ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀, wọ́n mú okùn ìkòkò ìse-ìrẹsì.

english: On 21, the police station told Deng's parent not to employ lawyer for Deng.
yoruba: Ní ọjọ́ 21, àwọn ọlọ́pàá sọ fún àwọn òbíi Deng láti máà gba agbẹjọ́rò fún un.

english: Deng, also known as Huang Huang, is an independent filmmaker who has collaborated with Beijing artist Ai Weiwei.
yoruba: Deng, tí a tún mọ̀ sí Huang Huang, tí ó jẹ́ ayàwòrán aládàádúró tí ó ti bá òǹyàwòrán Beijing, Ai Weiwei ṣiṣẹ́ papọ̀.

english: He claims to have previously faced intimidation by authorities, including detention in 2015 to prevent him from attending a human rights seminar in Geneva.
yoruba: Ó sọ wípé òun ti ní ìdojúkọ ìjọba, pẹ̀lú àtìmọ́lé ní ọdún-un 2015 láti dénà dè é kí ó máà lọ sí ìdánilẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ẹ̀tọ́ ọmọnìyàn ní Geneva.

english: Next month marks 30 years since the Tiananmen Square Massacre.
yoruba: Oṣù tí ó ń bọ̀ ni ó sààmì ọgbọ̀n ọdún tí ìpaninípakúpa Tiananmen Square wáyé.

english: Each year, Chinese authorities clamp down on references to the crackdown in the lead up to the anniversary, by placing outspoken dissidents on house arrest or in detention.
yoruba: Lọ́dọọdún, àwọn aláṣẹ China fi ọwọ́ agbára mú ìrántí ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ náà, tí wọ́n sì fi àwọn agbọ̀rọ̀dùn sí àtìmọ́lé.

english: A duty to remember: 30 years after Tiananmen
yoruba: Ojúṣe láti ṣe ìrántí: ọgbọ̀n ọdún lẹ́yìn Tiananmen

english: Installation made by Taiwanese artist Shake, and inspired by the photo of Tank Man displayed in central Taipei.
yoruba: Òǹyàwòrán ọmọ bíbí Taiwan Shake ni aṣàgbékalẹ̀, àwòrán Ọkùnrin Ọkọ̀ Ogun tí ó wà ní àárín gbùngùn-un Taipei ni ìmísí àgbékalẹ̀ náà.

english: Photo by Filip Noubel, used with permission.
yoruba: Filip Noubel ni ó ya àwòrán èyí, a fi àṣẹ lò ó.

english: It has been 30 years since the rise and fall of the 89 Democracy Movement (八九民运) in China that culminated in the infamous Tiananmen Square Massacre on June 4, 1989.
yoruba: Ó ti tó 30 ọdún sí ìgbà ìgbérí sókè àti ìṣubú Ẹgbẹ́ Olóṣèlú Ìjọba Àwa-ara-wa 89 (八九民运) ní China tí ó kóra jọ di Ìpaninípakúpa Gbàgede àìlókìkí Tiananmen Square ní ọjọ́ 4 oṣù Òkúdù, 1989.

english: On that day, the Chinese military carried out a brutal crackdown on student-led demonstrations calling for democratic reforms.
yoruba: Ní ọjọ́ yẹn, ikọ̀ ogun orílẹ̀-èdè China ṣíná bolẹ̀ fún àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ tí ó ń ṣe ìwọ́de ìfẹ̀hónúhàn àtúnṣe ètò ìjọba àwaarawa.

english: The Chinese Red Cross estimated that 2,700 civilians were killed, but other sources point to a much higher toll.
yoruba: Àjọ Alágbèélébùú Pupa ní yóò tó ọmọ orílẹ̀ 2,700 tí wọ́n pa, àmọ́ àwọn mìíràn nípé ó jù bẹ́ẹ̀ lọ.

english: A confidential US government document unveiled in 2014 reported that a Chinese internal assessment estimated that at least 10,454 civilians were killed.
yoruba: Àkọpamọ́ kan tí ó jẹ́ ti ìjọba US jábọ̀ ní ọdún-un 2014 wípé àyẹ̀wò tí ó wáyé nínú China sọ wípé yóò fẹ́rẹ̀ẹ́ tó ọmọ orílẹ̀ 10,454 tí wọ́n pa.

english: The Communist Party of China has never publicly acknowledged these events or accounted for its actions with an independent investigation.
yoruba: Ẹgbẹ́ Olóṣèlú The Communist Party ti China kò fi ìgbà kan sọ ọ́ ní gbangba rí wípé òún mọ̀ wípé ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ wọ̀nyí ṣẹ̀ tàbí ṣe ìwádìí fínnífínní síwájú sí i.

english: There are no references to the 89 Democracy Movement in any history textbooks and most university students in China have never heard about the massacre.
yoruba: Kò sí ìtọ́ka kankan sí Ẹgbẹ́ Olóṣèlú Ìjọba Àwa-ara-wa 89 nínú ìwé àkọsílẹ̀ ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ àtẹ̀yìnwá kankan, àwọn ọmọ ilé ìwé tí ó ga jù lọ ní China kò gbọ́ nípa ìpaninípakúpa náà, kò ta sí wọn létí rí.

english: Global Voices has been covering the issue for over a decade.
yoruba: Ohùn Àgbáyé ti ń jábọ̀ ìròyìn lórí ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ yìí fún ọdún mẹ́wàá.

english: This year we commemorate the 30th anniversary of what led to the June 4 massacre to fulfill our duty to keep the memory of those events alive, despite continuous efforts by Beijing to deny basic historical truth.
yoruba: Ní ọdún yìí ni a sààmì ọgbọ̀n ọdún ohun tí ó fa sábàbí ìpaninípakúpa ọjọ́ 4 oṣù Òkúdù àti láti ṣe ojúṣe wa láti rán àwọn ènìyàn létí, pẹ̀lú gbogbo ọ̀nà àgàbàgebè tí Beijing ń gbà láti fi eérú bo òtítọ́ mọ́lẹ̀.

english: Beijing’s determination to censor any mention or veiled reference to June 4 has resulted in a perpetual game of cat and mouse taking place online.
yoruba: Ìpinnu Beijing kò ju láti pa ohun gbogbo tí ó bá tan mọ́n ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ ọjọ́ 4 oṣù Òkúdù rẹ̀ lórí ayélujára.

english: In April, a foreign ad featuring images of the Tank Man circulated briefly on Chinese social media before being suppressed.
yoruba: Ní oṣù Igbe, ìpolówó òkè òkun kan tí ó ní àwòrán Ọkùnrin Ọkọ̀ Ogun fọ́nká sí orí ẹ̀rọ alátagbà orílẹ̀ èdèe China kí a tó mú un wálẹ̀.

english: Another of our stories explains how Chinese netizens play with censorship and come up with creative ways to allude to the event without mentioning it by its name, yet when they get caught, the punishment is immediate and severe.
yoruba: Òmíràn nínú àwọn ìròyìn-in wa ṣàlàyé bí àwọn ọmọ orílẹ̀ èdèe China tí ó wà lórí ayélujára ṣe máa ń fi ìpalẹ́numọ́ ṣeré àti wá ọ̀nà àrà tí wọ́n máa ń gbà sọ nípa ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ náà láì dárúkọ rẹ̀, bí wọ́n bá sì fi ọwọ́ọ ṣìgún òfin mú wọn, ìjìyà ojú ẹsẹ̀ tí ó kọjáa kékeré ni onítọ̀hún yóò jẹ ní agodo ọba.

english: All of this in an environment where obtaining information that is not filtered by China’s Great Firewall of online censorship has become very dangerous and almost impossible.
yoruba: Èyí ni àyíká tí ó mú ìkóròyìnjọ nira àti di ohun tí kò ṣe é ṣe nítorí gbogbo ìròyìn ní láti gba Asẹ́ Ńlá ìpalẹ́numọ́ orílẹ̀ èdèe China kọjá.

english: Expressing critical views on social media platforms outside of China also poses a personal risk, as you can read in this story.
yoruba: Bẹ́ẹ̀ náà ni ìfojúṣùnnùnkùn wo ọ̀rọ̀ lórí ẹ̀rọ alátagbà ní ẹ̀yin odi orílẹ̀ èdèe China náà mú ewu tirẹ̀ lọ́wọ́, gẹ́gẹ́ bí o ti ṣe kà nínú ìròyìn yìí.

english: And expressing alternative views not aligned with the Party’s line, even if embedded in Marxism, usually results in harassment and arrest, as we describe here.
yoruba: Àtìmọ́lé àti ifipámúni ni èrè ẹ̀ṣẹ̀ ẹni tí ó bá sọ èròńgbà tirẹ̀ tí ó yàtọ̀ sí ti Ẹgbẹ́ olóṣèlú ìjọba, bí a ṣe ṣàpèjúwe níbí.

english: This draconian censorship is being exported worldwide by Beijing, including to Hong Kong.
yoruba: Irú ìpalẹ́numọ́ onísànánjúpa Beijing báwọ̀nyí ti ń kárí ayé, títí kan Hong Kong.

english: Yet the duty to remember continues to inspire people and netizens across the globe.
yoruba: Síbẹ̀ ojúṣe láti rántí kò dẹ́kun fífi ìmísí sí ọkàn àwọn ènìyàn àti àwọn ọmọ orílẹ̀ èdè káàkiri àgbáyé.

english: Direct witnesses speak up in emotional interviews, while brave journalists in Hong Kong tell their own stories about June 4.
yoruba: Àwọn tí ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ náà ṣe ojúu wọn fọ ohun tí ó ń gbé wọn lọ́kàn síta nínú ìfọ̀rọ̀wọ́rọ̀, bí àwọn akọni òǹkọ̀ròyìn ní Hong Kong ṣe ń kọ ìròyìn nípa ọjọ́ 4 oṣù Òkúdù.

english: Hong Kong also hosts copies of the most emblematic symbol of the movement, the Goddess of Democracy in public space.
yoruba: Níṣe ni Hong Kong kún fún àwòrán ìdánimọ̀ ẹgbẹ́ náà, òrìṣà abo ti Àwaarawa ní ìta gbangba.

english: In Taiwan, a powerful art installation displayed in central Taipei pays tribute to the events of 1989.
yoruba: Ní Taiwan, àgbékalẹ̀ẹ ọnà alágbára kan tí a gbé sí àárín gbùngbùn Taipei ń ṣe ìrántí àwọn ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ ọdún-un 1989.

english: Global netizens, including Reddit users, also use humor, art, and online memes to keep the memory of the Chinese pro-democracy movement alive.
yoruba: Àwọn ọmọ orí ayélujára Àgbáyé, títí kan àwọn tí ó ń lo Reddit, náà ń lo ẹ̀fẹ̀, ọnà àti àwòrán orí ayélujára tí a fi àyọkà sínúu rẹ̀ rán ni létí nípa ìjàgbara ọ̀rọ̀ ìjọba àwaarawa.

english: Jamaica’s ‘Voices for Climate Change’ spreads its message with music
yoruba: ‘Ohùn-un Jamaica fún Àyípadà Ojú-ọjọ́’ fi orin jíṣẹ́ẹ wọn

english: Screenshot from the YouTube video "Voices for Climate Change Education – 2019 Campaign", published by Panos Caribbean.
yoruba: Àwòrán láti fídíò oríi YouTube “Ohùn fún Àyípadà Ojú-ọjọ́ fún Ẹ̀kọ́ Àyípadà Ojú-ọjọ́ – Ìpolongo ọdún 2019,” tí Panos Caribbean tẹ̀ jáde.

english: The organisation has launched an eight-month climate change community awareness campaign in four communities across Jamaica: Rocky Point and Lionel Town in the parish of Clarendon, Ridge Red Bank in St. Elizabeth and White River in St Ann.
yoruba: Iléeṣẹ́ náà ti ṣe ìfilọ́lẹ̀ ìpolongo ìkéde àyípadà ojú-ọjọ́ ní agbègbè mẹ́rin ní àárín-in Jamaica: Rocky Point àti Lionel Town ní ẹ̀ka ìlúu Clarendon, Ridge Red Bank ní St. Elizabeth àti White River ní St Ann.

english: From reggae and dancehall music to jingles extolling the virtues of everything from laundry detergent to fast food, the way to any Jamaican’s heart is through song — prompting Panos Caribbean, a media-savvy non-governmental organisation, to take a musical approach to spread its environmental message.
yoruba: Bí orin reggae àti dancehall ṣe ń lọ ni àwọn ìpolongo tí ó ń sọ nípa ohun gbogbo láti ọṣẹ ìfọṣọ àbùfọ̀ sí oúnjẹ àsèsílẹ̀, orin ni ènìyán lè gbà dé ọkàn ọmọ Jamaica — èyí ló mú Panos Caribbean, ẹni tí ó ní ilé iṣẹ́ ìròyìn tí kì í ṣe ti ìjọba, láti fi orin kéde nípa ọ̀rọ̀ àyíká.

english: The organisation has been successfully sharing critical information with the public through its Voices for Climate Change project.
yoruba: Iléeṣẹ́ náà ti yege nínúu ìtànká àwọn ìkéde tí ó ṣe kókó nípasẹ̀ẹ iṣẹ́ Ohùn fún Àyípadà Ojú-ọjọ́.

english: Those voices rang out loud and clear at the historic United Nations Conference in Paris (COP21) in 2015.
yoruba: Kedere ni ohùn ń jáde láti inú ilé àpérò ìlú-mọ̀ńká United Nations Conference ní Paris (COP21) lọ́dún-un 2015.

english: There, Jamaican singer and songwriter Aaron Silk joined forces with other musicians — including Belizean performer Adrian Martinez — to advocate for a 1.5-degree limit to global warming.
yoruba: Níbẹ̀, ọ̀kọrin ọmọ Jamaica Aaron Silk darapọ̀ mọ́ àwọn olórin mìíràn — pẹ̀lú eléré Belizean Adrian Martinez — láti ṣe alágbàáwí ìdínkù fún ìgbóná àgbáyé sí ìwọ̀n-ọn ojúàmì 1.5.

english: The musical message, which supported the position of Small Island Developing States, was considerable, influencing the aspirations reflected in COP21’s final document.
yoruba: Ìfiránṣẹ́ olórin náà, tí ó ṣe àtìlẹ́yìn, ipòo ti ìdásílẹ̀ Ìpínlẹ̀ Erékùṣù Kéékèèké Tí-ó-ń-gòkè, jẹ́ ohun àfiyèsí, tí ó ń ní ipa nínúu ìwé-ìpamọ́ ìkẹyìn-in ti COP21.

english: Years later, the “1.5” message continues to resonate in the eastern Caribbean, where singers have intertwined St. Lucian poet Kendel Hippolyte’s words with their own lyrics in order to ensure the message hits home.
yoruba: Ọdún gorí ọdún, iṣẹ́ “1.5 túbọ̀ ń rinlẹ̀ sí i ní ìlà-oòrùn Caribbean, níbi tí àwọn ọ̀kọrin ti ṣe àlọ́pọ̀ ọ̀rọ̀ akéwì St. Lucian Kendel Hippolyte’s pẹ̀lú orin-in ti wọn láti ṣe àrídájú wípé iṣẹ́ náà dé ibi tí ó yẹ kí ó dé.

english: Community artist Sammy Junior, from Rocky Point, Clarendon (a community impacted by sea level rise and coastal erosion) at a workshop on Climate Change Messaging in Jamaica on March 14, 2019.
yoruba: Olùyàwòrán agbègbè Sammy Junior, láti Rocky Point, Clarendon (agbègbè tí ìrúsókè-odò ọ̀sà àti àgbàrá ibi tí ó súnmọ́ omi ti kó bá) níbi ìdánilẹ́kọ̀ọ́ tí ó dá lóríi Ìfiṣẹ́ránṣẹ́ Àyípadà Ojú-ọjọ́ ní Jamaica ní ọjọ́ 14 oṣù Ẹrẹ́nà, ọdún-un 2019.

english: Photo by Emma Lewis, used with permission.
yoruba: Àwòrán-an Emma Lewis, pẹ̀lú àṣẹ ni a fi lò ó.

english: The climate change crisis in 2019 is even more urgent than it was four years ago and in Jamaica, rural citizens from farmers to fisherfolk are heeding the wake-up call.
yoruba: Wàhálà àyípadà ojú-ọjọ́ ní ọdún-un 2019 jẹ́ ohun tí ó nílò àbójútó kíákíá ju ti ìdúnrin lọ, àti ní Jamaica, àwọn ará ìgbèríko tí ó jẹ́ àgbẹ̀, àwọn apẹja ń gbọ́ ìpè itanijí yìí.

english: Artists, schoolchildren and community members came together in different parts of Jamaica — Kingston, Lionel Town, Ridge Red Bank and White River — for four days of workshops during the months of March and April.
yoruba: Akọrin, ọmọ ilé ìwé àti àwọn aládùúgbò péjọ ní — Kingston, Lionel Town, Ridge Red Bank àti White River — fún ìdánilẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ọlọ́jọ́ mẹ́rin nínúu oṣù Ẹrẹ́nà àti Igbe.

english: There, they honed their communication skills and learned about the impact of climate change.
yoruba: Níbẹ̀, wọ́n fi ẹ̀kọ́ kún ẹ̀kọ́ ìmọ̀ ìtàkùrọ̀sọ àti kọ́ nípa ipa àyípadà ojú-ọjọ́.

english: Powerful lyrics emerged, ideas flowed and eye-opening field trips provided on-the-ground perspectives:
yoruba: Ọ̀rọ̀ orin tí ó lágbára gbérí, ọgbọ́n ń tayọ àti ìrìnàjò ìṣíjú ojú ẹsẹ̀:

english: Translation Original Quote
yoruba: Ìtúmọ̀ Ìtúnwí-ọ̀rọ̀ Ọlọ́rọ̀ gan-an

english: Mother Earth she bawls
yoruba: Ìyá Ilẹ̀-ayé ń ké tantan

english: Deep in the forest where the trees fall
yoruba: Nínú igbó kìjikìji níbi tí àwọn igi ń wó sí

english: Look upon the reef, see the fish how small
yoruba: Wo òkúta ìsàlẹ̀ òkun, wo ẹja bí ó ṣe kéré

english: Give them a little time, make them grow big and tall
yoruba: Fún wọn ní àsìkò, jẹ́ kí wọ́n dàgbà àti ga

english: Artists from Kingston, Clarendon and Spanish Town working together on lyrics at the Climate Change Messaging workshop.
yoruba: Àwọn akọrin láti Kingston, Clarendon àti Spanish Town ń ṣiṣẹ́ pọ̀ lóríi ọ̀rọ̀ orin níbi ìdánilẹ́kọ̀ọ́ Ìfiṣẹ́ránṣẹ́ Àyípadà Ojú-ọjọ́.

english: Photo by Emma Lewis, used with permission.
yoruba: Àwòrán-an Emma Lewis, a lò ó pẹ̀lú àṣẹ.

english: With Panos’ launch of a new Caribbean theme song for Earth Day, the Jamaican group is booked solid for school and community concerts, as well as the Read Across Jamaica initiative and tree-planting sessions.
yoruba: Pẹ̀lú ìfilọ́lẹ̀ẹ Panos fún àkòrí orin tuntun fún Caribbean fún Àyájọ́ Ilẹ̀-ayé, ẹgbẹ́ẹ Jamaica náà ti ṣe tán láti ṣe eré ní iléèwé àti ní àdúgbò, láì yọ Kàwé Jákèjádò Jamaica sílẹ̀ àti iṣẹ́ igi gbíngbìn.
